page.title: Children with Special Healthcare Needs in the United States

revision.text:
'''Children with Special Healthcare Needs''' (CSHCN) are defined by the [[Maternal and Child Health Bureau]] as: :"Those who have one or more chronic physical, developmental, behavioral, or emotional conditions and who :also require health and related services of a type or amount beyond that required by children generally" <ref name="McPherson">McPherson, M., P. Arango, H. Fox, C. Lauver, M. McManus, P. W. Newacheck, J. M. Perrin, J. P. Shonkoff, and B. Strickland. "A New Definition of Children With Special Health Care Needs." Pediatrics 102.1 (1998): 137-39. Print.</ref>
==Types of special healthcare needs== There are a wide variety of physical, mental, and psychological health conditions considered to be special healthcare needs in the United States. They range from relatively mild to chronic and severe. The functional impairments of CSHCN include problems with one or more of the following criteria: breathing, swallowing/digestion/metabolism, blood circulation, chronic pain, hearing even with corrective devices, seeing even with corrective devices, taking care of self, coordination/moving around, learning/understanding/paying attention, speaking/communicating, making/keeping friends, and behavior.<ref name="Data">National Survey of Children with Special Health Care Needs. NS-CSHCN 2009/10. Data query from the Child and Adolescent Health Measurement Initiative, Data Resource Center for Child and Adolescent Health website. Retrieved [10/25/12] from www.childhealthdata.org</ref> The list below states health conditions considered to be special healthcare needs. *[[Attention Deficit Disorder]] (ADD) *Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) *[[Depression (mood)|Depression]] *Anxiety problems *Behavioral problems *[[Autism Spectrum Disorders]] (ASD) *[[Diabetes]] *[[Developmental delay]] *[[Intellectual Disability]] (ID) *[[Epilepsy]] *[[Migraines]] *[[Traumatic Brain Injury]] (TBI) *Heart problems *Blood problems *[[Cystic fibrosis]] *[[Cerebral palsy]] *[[Muscular dystrophy]] *[[Down syndrome]] *[[Arthritis]] *Joint problems *Allergies
==Population== As of 2009, 15.1% of all children in the US are considered to have special healthcare needs,<ref name="Context">U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Health Resources and Services Administration, Maternal and Child Health Bureau. Children with Special Health Care Needs in Context: A Portrait of States and the Nation 2007. Rockville, Maryland: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2011.</ref> and one out of every five households in the United States has at least one child with special healthcare needs, representing a significant segment of the nation's population.<ref name="Data"/>
===Epidemiology=== The prevalence of children with special healthcare needs in the population depends on several factors, including gender, age, socioeconomic level and family household education.<ref name="Epidemiologic">Newacheck PW; Strickland B; Shonkoff JP; Perrin JM; McPherson M; McManus M; Lauver C; Fox H; Arango, P. "An Epidemiologic Profile Of Children With Special Health Care Needs." Pediatrics 102.1 Pt 1 (1998): 117-123. MEDLINE. Web. 29 Nov. 2012</ref> In the National Survey of Children's Health Data in 2007, gender is the strongest predictor of special health care needs—about 60% of children with special health care needs are boys and 30% are girls.<ref name="Data"/> A study by Newacheck et al. found that age is also a strong predictor, as school-age children are found to be twice as likely as toddlers to require special needs care, and this prevalence continues to increase as children grow older.<ref name="Epidemiologic"/> Families with income below the [[Poverty in the United States|federal poverty level]] are 1/3 more likely to have children with special health care needs, and families with 12 or fewer years of education have increased prevalence of a child with SHCN as well.<ref name="Epidemiologic"/> Family structure also correlates with this prevalence—for [[Single parent|single-mother]] families are 40% more likely to have a CSHCN than two-parent households.<ref name="Epidemiologic"/>
===Challenges=== In a comprehensive study by the U.S. [[Health Resources and Services Administration]] (HRSA), using the 2007 National Survey of Children's Health data, it was found that children with SHCN when compared to those children without SHCN, face more inadequacies in healthcare, education, health of family, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle.<ref name="Context"/> CSHCN face more difficulties with accessing mental health care <ref name="Context"/> as well as having a [[medical home]]. A medical home is one of the standards of administering healthcare recommended by the Maternal and Child Health Bureau.<ref name="AAP"/> In school, these children have an increased risk of missing class, being disengaged in the classroom, and repeating a grade.<ref name="Context"/> They also have more cases of inadequate sleep every night in comparison to their peers.<ref name="Context"/> CSHCN are more likely to not exercise the recommended four times a week, and they have higher chance of being overweight/obese.<ref name="Context"/> They also face increased challenges in making friends.<ref name="Context"/> The parents of CSHCN have challenges as well. The study by HRSA, found that the parents of special needs children experience more stress, decreased health, and more questioning of their parenting skills.<ref name="Context"/>
Despite these challenges, children with SHCN fare better than non-affected children in preventative health care and preventative dental care.<ref name="Context"/> They have a higher rate of having health insurance then normal children.<ref name="Data"/> They more frequently complete the recommended annual primary care visit, and bi-annual dentist visit.<ref name="Data"/> They also have a tendency to use more Developmental Screening, especially those with public healthcare.<ref name="Context"/> Developmental screening is used by doctors to check and evaluate for proper child development over time on a physical and cognitive level. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends visits for developmental screening at ages 9,18 and at 24–30 months.<ref name="Developmental">Developmental Monitoring and Screening." Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 12 July 2012. Web. 29 Nov. 2012. <https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/childdevelopment/screening.html>.</ref>
===Challenges for CSHCN with emotional and behavioral disorders=== [[Emotional and behavioral disorders]] (EBD) are disorders that include ADD/ADHD, anxiety, ASD, depression, OCD/conduct disorder, developmental delay and Tourette's Syndrome, and they increase the challenges CSHCN face.<ref name="Context"/> 40% of CSHCN have an EBD and 80% of these children also experience another health problem along with their EBD, according to the 2007 National Survey of Children's Health.<ref name="Data"/> The Health Resources and Services Administration found that these disorders are associated with an even greater decrease in quality of family-life, education and healthcare.<ref name="Context"/> Parent's health worsens and stress increases when they have children with an EBD.<ref name="Context"/> These EBD children miss more classes and are more disengaged in class than non-EBD CSHCN.<ref name="Context"/> EBD-CSHCN experience reduced family center-care and effective care-coordination.<ref name="Context"/> They also face greater difficulty in their ability to make friends than non-EBD CSHCN.<ref name="Context"/>
===Effective Support for Families=== A systematic review of randomized controlled trials found evidence that
* Including parents in psychological therapies to help children manage painful conditions was effective; * Cognitive behavioral therapy that includes parents reduces primary symptoms; * Problem solving therapy for parents improves their skills and mental health.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Eccleston, C |author2=Palermo, TM |author3=Fisher, E |title= Psychological interventions for parents of children and adolescents with chronic illness |journal=Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews |year=2012 |volume=8|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD009660|display-authors=etal|pmc=3551454}}</ref>
==United states government involvement== The United States governments employs several different programs in order to provide insurance and care for CSHCN. These include Title V grants, Medicaid and Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP). These three programs vary in their definition and eligibility of care for CSHCN.<ref name="McPherson"/>
===Medicaid=== [[Medicaid]] is the program implemented under Title XIX of the Social Security Act.<ref name="Title XIX">United States. TITLE XIX—GRANTS TO STATES FOR MEDICAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. Social Security Act §1900. Web. 29 Nov. 2012. <http://www.ssa.gov/OP_Home/ssact/title19/1900.htm>.</ref> It is a public insurance program that provides mandatory services for patients such as: *Inpatient/outpatient hospital resources *Transportation for non-emergency medical care *Home health services *Laboratory procedures *Physician services *[[Family planning]] *Nursing facilities *Early Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment (EPDST) program *Tobacco cessation programs for pregnant women Medicaid requires no co-payment or deductibles. To be eligible for the program one must be in one of four categories. The first is income level, the second is disability criteria, the third is eligibility for institutional level of care, and the fourth is out of home placement. Many CSHCN qualify for Medicaid based on low income level, but some children qualify independently of income level due to their disabilities. Medicaid has a more restrictive definition of disabilities and special healthcare needs than the Maternal and Children's Health Bureau (MCHB), and defines special needs as needs that must impede daily functioning. Medicaid accepts children who need to receive Supplemental Security Income program money, and children who are defined as medically needy.<ref name="Title XIX"/><ref name="Basic"/> Medically needy children are those whose families have above the maximum income to receive Medicaid, but due to health expenditures their income is lowered to the level required. 40 states currently offer this program.<ref name="Medically Needy">Crowley, Jeff. "Medicaid Medically Needy Programs: An Important Source of Medicaid Coverage." Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, 2003. Web. 29 Nov. 2012. <http://www.kff.org/medicaid/loader.cfm?url=/commonspot/security/getfile.cfm>.</ref> Medicaid programs in each state are administered differently, and federal dollars go to each state based on per capita income levels. As of 2010, the Medicaid program had 405 billion dollars for the entire program. With the new [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]], by 2014 state Medicaid levels will rise to 138% of the Federal Poverty Line, increasing the number of CSHCN receiving Medicaid.<ref name="Title XIX"/><ref name="Basic"/>
===Children's health insurance program=== This program, the [[Children's Health Insurance Program]] (CHIP), was created with Title XXI of the Social Security Act,<ref name="Title XXI">"TITLE XXI—STATE CHILDREN’S HEALTH INSURANCE PROGRAM." Social Security Act Title XXI. USA Government, n.d. Web. 29 Nov. 2012. <http://www.ssa.gov/OP_Home/ssact/title21/2100.htm></ref> and is meant to cover the gap between children who qualify for Medicaid and those who can afford private insurance.<ref name="Basic"/> It covers children up to nineteen years of age and many states also choose to help insure pregnant women. 46 of the states and the District of Columbia insure up to 200% of the Federal Poverty Line. CHIP receives its funding from the federal government but it is capped, unlike Medicaid. CSHCN who use CHIP receive all of the same federally mandated programs that Medicaid must offer. The program also requires that mental health services be offered as equally as physical health services.<ref name="Basic"/><ref name="Title XXI"/>
===Title V=== This [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] Act, Title V, states that $850,000,000 in grant money is to be allotted starting in 2001 and every year after to the states in order to accomplish health goals of the Public Health Service Act as well as the goals of Title V. The Title V grant money is set out to specifically affect CSHCN in several ways. First, it requires states to provide rehabilitation services for blind or disabled individuals under the age of 16. It also allocates money to projects of both national and state importance that help maternal and child health as well as children with special healthcare needs. The act requires that there are community-based programs such as daycare that help provide for CSHCN. Another requirement is the creation of family-to-family health information centers that assist families with CSHCN to make informed decisions regarding healthcare and resources.<ref name="Title V">Title V "Social Security Act 501." Social Security Online. USA Government, n.d. Web. 25 Oct. 2012. <http://www.ssa.gov/OP_Home/ssact/title05/0501.htm.>.</ref>
This program works with the [[Maternal and Child Health Bureau]], and employs their definition of CSHCN as stated earlier. Title V does not provide as much money as CHIP or Medicaid, but is used to fill the gaps where these programs do not cover. The Title V money is used to help with the Early Periodic Screening Diagnosis and Treatment Program (EPSDT) that is employed by Medicaid to test children. Title V shares the data collection responsibility of these three programs as well as develops educational materials. The Title V programs also have the goal to promote community-based services for all children as well as to promote coordinated care for families.<ref name="Title V"/><ref name="Basic">Rosenthal, Jill, Mary Hendersen, Catherine Hess, Carol Tobias, Sara Bachman, and Meg Comeau. "Public Insurance Programs and Children with Special Health Care Needs, A Tutorial on the Basics of Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program." (2011): n. pag. Web. 25 Oct. 2012 <http://www.nashp.org/sites/default/files/Medicaid_101_tutorial.pdf>.</ref>
==Childhood Care== Children with special healthcare needs require more healthcare for their various health conditions as well as more types of therapies and treatments.<ref name="Data"/> Therapies include [[occupational therapy]], [[physical therapy]], and [[speech-language pathology]] among others.
===Medical home=== The [[American Academy of Pediatrics]] (AAP) medical home model is the suggested form of healthcare administration for children with special health care needs due to their increased healthcare needs.<ref name="AAP"/> In a study by Judith Palfrey et al. it was found to indicate improved health and increase patient satisfaction.<ref name="Evaluation">{{cite journal | author = Palfrey Judith S., MD , Sofis Lisa A., Davidson Emily J., Liu Jihong, PhD , Freeman Linda, -1#PhD MS, Ganz Michael L. | year = 2004 | title = The Pediatric Alliance for Coordinated Care: Evaluation of a Medical Home Model | url = http://www.pediatricsdigest.mobi/content/113/Supplement_4/1507.short | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 113 | issue = | pages = 1507–516 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> This model as defined by the AAP is a total coordination of care for infants, children and adolescents. It consists of a primary physician, preferably a pediatrician, that a child and their family know well and who is a medical advocate for the care of the child. All medical care in the medical home is accessible, continuous, comprehensive, family-centered, compassionate and coordinated.<ref name="AAP"/> This model requires several elements: *Provision of preventative care *Assurance of ambulatory/inpatient care at any time *Provision of care over a long period of time *Ability to identify need for sub-specialists and to make these referrals *Interaction with the school and community programs of a child to work with a child's special needs *Central record keeping data base The pediatrician assumes the ultimate responsibility for all care that is provided for the child even though other medical professionals are involved.<ref name="AAP">"The Medical Home." Pediatrics 90.5 (1992): 774. The Medical Home. Pediatrics, 1992. Web. 25 Oct. 2012 <http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/90/5/774.abstract>.</ref> Currently, 48.9% of CSHCN have access to a medical home while 59.6% of non-affected children have access to a medical home. .<ref name="Data"/>
===Therapy for CSHCN=== Therapies for children with special healthcare needs can be accessed via public schools or private therapists. The [[Individuals with Disabilities Education Act]] (IDEA) includes occupational and physical therapy as well as other therapies, as part of the [[special education]] that should be offered in all public schools to CSHCN. This act states that all children with disabilities should have access to education that suits their SHCN, including needed therapies.<ref name="OTPT">Bober, Patricia, MS, OT, and Sandra Corbett, PT. "Occupational Therapy and Physical Therapy: A Resource and Planning Guide." Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction, 2011. Web. 29 Nov. 2012. <http://sped.dpi.wi.gov/files/sped/pdf/ot-pt-guide-2nd-edition.pdf>.</ref><ref name="IDEA">Assistance to States for the Education of Children With Disabilities and Preschool Grants for Children With Disabilities, 71 C.F.R. § 300 and 301 et seq. (2006). Web. 29 Nov 2012. <http://idea.ed.gov/download/finalregulations.pdf></ref> Out of school therapies can also be used be employed by children with SHCN but only 3.2% of CSHCN qualify for uses of special therapy under their insurance programs.<ref name="Data"/>
One type of therapy for children with SHCN is occupational therapy. Occupational therapists work with CSHCN by supporting them and their families to learn how to participate in everyday routines and daily activities. They encourage children with physical, cognitive, communication and behavior challenges to develop ways to live, play, learn and make friends despite their special needs.<ref name="AOTA"> "Occupational Therapy for Young Children." The American Occupational Therapy Association, Inc. AOTA, n.d. Web. 29 Nov. 2012. <http://www.aota.org/Consumers/Professionals/WhatIsOT/CY/Fact-Sheets/Children.aspx>.</ref> Occupational therapists can work with these children and their schools to create more accommodating learning environments. Another skill these professionals teach to children with SHCN is how to use adaptive equipment such as wheelchairs, eating aids and braces in daily life. Some occupational therapists try to work with very young children at risk for SHCN in order to try and prevent future disability through occupational therapy.<ref name="Labor">Bureau of Labor Statistics, U.S. Department of Labor, Occupational Outlook Handbook, 2012-13 Edition, Occupational Therapists, on the Internet at http://www.bls.gov/ooh/healthcare/occupational-therapists.htm (visited November 29, 2012).</ref>
===Insurance for CSHCN=== The types of insurance vary for children with special healthcare needs, 9.3% of CSHCN have no insurance at all, 52.4% have private insurance, 35.9% have public insurance and 8.2% have some combination of both public and private.<ref name="Data"/> Insurance gaps and other health costs affect 21.6% of families with CSHCN, who state that they face financial problems due to their CSHCN. In total, 34.3% of these families believe that their current insurance is not adequate in providing for all of their additional healthcare costs.<ref name="Data"/>
==Adult care== The Maternal and Child Health Bureau requires services to be available that are necessary for CSHCN to transition to all aspects of adult life.<ref name="Evidence">{{cite journal | author = Homer Charles J., Klatka Kirsten, Romm Diane, Kulthau Karen, Bloom Sheila, Newacheck Paul, Jeanne , Cleave Van, Perrin James M. | year = 2008 | title = A Review of the Evidence for the Medical Home for Children With Special Health Care Needs | url = http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/122/4/e922.full.html | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 122 | issue = | pages = 922–37 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> 90% of Adolescents with SHCN (ASHCN) are expected to live into adulthood, and access to healthcare decreases as ASHCN grow older according to the Maternal and Child Health Bureau.<ref name="Association"/> Youth lose health coverage they received in the past from programs like CHIP as well as Supplemental Security Income once they reach the ages of 18-21. Adult healthcare providers are not as familiar with childhood onset conditions as pediatricians.<ref name="Association">"Youth and Young Adult Transition- Children’s Medical Service." Association of Maternal and Child Health Programs, May 2011. Web. 12 Nov. 2012 <http://www.amchp.org/programsandtopics/BestPractices/InnovationStation/ISDocs/CMS-CSHCN%20transitions.pdf>.</ref> A study by Jane Park et al. found that mental health conditions increase in prevalence as children get older and age into adulthood, and ASHCN who have mental health conditions (with or without physical conditions) fare worse on their transition to adult healthcare.<ref name="Young">{{cite journal |pmid=21296043 | doi=10.1016/j.acap.2010.11.010 | volume=11 | title=Health care services and the transition to young adulthood: challenges and opportunities | year=2011 | journal=Acad Pediatr | pages=115–22 |vauthors=Park MJ, Adams SH, Irwin CE }}</ref> The MCHB recommends that children should have their transition to adult healthcare be mediated and provided for by their doctors. The Bureau requires that doctors need to have discussed with the adolescents with SHCN and their families three points: how to transition to adult primary care doctors as opposed to pediatricians, how health needs will change as the youth become adults, and how to maintain health insurance as an adult. The doctor is also supposed to encourage youth to take responsibility for their own health needs.<ref name="Association"/> Currently 60% of doctors of adolescents with SHCN do not meet these criteria.<ref name="Data"/>
===Healthcare transition plan===
Another recommendation for healthcare providers by the Maternal and Child Health Bureau is the creation of a written Healthcare Transition (HCT) plan.<ref name="Association"/> According to a study by Peter Scal and Marjorie Ireland, 30.08% of ASHCN had discussed such a plan. It was also found that adolescents who were older and who had more complicated needs were more likely to have an HCT.<ref name="Transition">Scal, Peter, MD. MPH, and Marjorie Ireland, PhD. "Addressing Transition to Adult Health Care for Adolescents With Special Health Care Needs." Pediatrics 115.6 (2005): 1607-612. Addressing Transition to Adult Health Care for Adolescents With Special Health Care Needs. Web. 12 Nov. 2012. <http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/115/6/1607.full>.</ref>
===Patient protection and affordable care act=== The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act passed by the Obama administration in 2010 sets forth new requirements for ability of adolescents with SHCN to transition healthcare services from pediatric services. The Act also expands their ability to pay for and access these services.<ref name="ACA">Pub.L. 111-148, 124 Stat. 119, to be codified as amended at scattered sections of the Internal Revenue Code and in 42 U.S.C.</ref> It states three criteria that must be met for adolescents. First, adolescents need to have access to a comprehensive healthcare system that they can find a way to pay for, as well as be able to navigate the system. Second, preventable health problems need to be successfully prevented. Third, chronic conditions need to be managed and the transition to adult healthcare needs to be assured. Skills that ASHCN are recommended to possess to accomplish these goals include the ability to describe their own illness, know their own medication and dosages, know how to contact a clinician, and the ability to schedule appointments and call in for refills.<ref name="Young"/><ref name="ACA"/>

{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Choroideremia | synonyms = | image = File:Sex linked inheritance.png | caption = An example pedigree chart, showing the inheritance of a sex-linked disorder like choroideremia. | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Choroideremia''' ({{IPAc-en|k|ɒ|ˌ|r|ɔɪ|d|ᵻ|ˈ|r|iː|m|i|ə}}; '''CHM''') is a rare, [[X-linked]] [[recessive]] form of hereditary [[retina]]l degeneration that affects roughly 1 in 50,000 males. The disease causes a gradual loss of vision, starting with childhood [[Nyctalopia|night blindness]], followed by peripheral vision loss, and progressing to loss of central vision later in life. Progression continues throughout the individual's life, but both the rate of change and the degree of visual loss are variable among those affected, even within the same family.<ref name = "Karna">{{cite journal|last1=Kärnä|first1=J|title=Choroideremia. A clinical and genetic study of 84 Finnish patients and 126 female carriers.|journal=Acta Ophthalmologica Supplement|date=1986|volume=176|pages=1–68|pmid=3014804}}</ref>
Choroideremia is caused by a [[null allele|loss-of-function]] mutation in the ''CHM'' [[gene]] which encodes [[Rab escort protein 1]] (REP1), a protein involved in lipid modification of [[Rab (G-protein)|Rab proteins]]. While the complete mechanism of disease is not fully understood, the lack of a functional protein in the retina results in cell death and the gradual deterioration of the [[retinal pigment epithelium]] (RPE), [[photoreceptor cell|photoreceptors]], and the [[choroid]].<ref name = "Roberts">{{cite journal|last1=Roberts|first1=MF|last2=Fishman|first2=GA|last3=Roberts|first3=DK|last4=Heckenlively|first4=JR|last5=Weleber|first5=RG|last6=Anderson|first6=RJ|last7=Grover|first7=S|title=Retrospective, longitudinal, and cross sectional study of visual acuity impairment in choroideraemia.|journal=The British Journal of Ophthalmology|date=June 2002|volume=86|issue=6|pages=658–62|pmid=12034689|doi=10.1136/bjo.86.6.658|pmc=1771148}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Aleman|first1=TS|last2=Han|first2=G|last3=Serrano|first3=LW|last4=Fuerst|first4=NM|last5=Charlson|first5=ES|last6=Pearson|first6=DJ|last7=Chung|first7=DC|last8=Traband|first8=A|last9=Pan|first9=W|last10=Ying|first10=GS|last11=Bennett|first11=J|last12=Maguire|first12=AM|last13=Morgan|first13=JI|title=Natural History of the Central Structural Abnormalities in Choroideremia: A Prospective Cross-Sectional Study.|journal=Ophthalmology|date=13 December 2016|doi=10.1016/j.ophtha.2016.10.022|pmid=27986385|volume=124|issue=3|pmc=5319901|pages=359–373}}</ref>
As of 2018, there is no treatment for choroideremia; however, [[Gene therapy of the human retina|retinal]] [[gene therapy]] clinical trials have demonstrated a possible treatment.<ref>Abigail Beall, 2014, "Gene therapy restores sight in people with eye disease," ''New Scientist'' (online), January 16, 2014, see [https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn24879-gene-therapy-restores-sight-in-people-with-eye-disease.html#.VTkaJTf_SOJ], accessed 21 January 2017.</ref>
==Presentation==
Since the ''CHM'' gene is located on the [[X chromosome]], symptoms are seen almost exclusively in men. While there are a few exceptions, female [[genetic carrier|carriers]] have a noticeable lack of pigmentation in the RPE but do not experience any symptoms.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dugel|first1=Pravin U.|last2=Zimmer|first2=Cheryl N.|last3=Shahidi|first3=Ayda M.|title=A case study of choroideremia carrier – Use of multi-spectral imaging in highlighting clinical features|journal=American Journal of Ophthalmology Case Reports|date=July 2016|volume=2|pages=18–22|doi=10.1016/j.ajoc.2016.04.003|pmid=29503891|pmc=5757363}}</ref> Female carriers have a 50% chance of having either an affected son or a carrier daughter, while a male with choroideremia will have all carrier daughters and unaffected sons. Even though the disease progression can vary significantly,<ref name = "Karna"/><ref>{{Cite book|last1=Strunnikova|first1=N|last2=Zein|first2=WM|last3=Silvin|first3=C|last4=MacDonald|first4=IM|title=Serum biomarkers and trafficking defects in peripheral tissues reflect the severity of retinopathy in three brothers affected by choroideremia.|journal=Advances in Experimental Medicine and Biology|date=2012|volume=723|pages=381–7|pmid=22183356|doi=10.1007/978-1-4614-0631-0_49|isbn=978-1-4614-0630-3}}</ref> there are general trends. The first symptom many individuals with choroideremia notice is a significant loss of night vision, which begins in youth.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Khan|first1=Kamron N.|last2=Islam|first2=Farrah|last3=Moore|first3=Anthony T.|last4=Michaelides|first4=Michel|title=Clinical and Genetic Features of Choroideremia in Childhood|journal=Ophthalmology|date=October 2016|volume=123|issue=10|pages=2158–2165|doi=10.1016/j.ophtha.2016.06.051|pmid=27506488|url=http://discovery.ucl.ac.uk/1508714/|type=Submitted manuscript}}</ref> [[Peripheral vision]] loss occurs gradually, starting as a ring of vision loss, and continuing on to "tunnel vision" in adulthood.<ref name = "GeneReviews">{{cite journal|last1=MacDonald|first1=Ian M.|last2=Hume|first2=Stacey|last3=Chan|first3=Stephanie|last4=Seabra|first4=Miguel C.|title=Choroideremia|journal=GeneReviews(®)|date=February 26, 2015|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1337/|publisher=University of Washington, Seattle}}</ref> Individuals with choroideremia tend to maintain good [[visual acuity]] into their 40s, but eventual lose all sight at some point in the 50-70 age range.<ref name = "GeneReviews"/> A study of 115 individuals with choroideremia found that 84% of patients under the age of 60 had a visual acuity of [[Snellen chart|20/40]] or better, while 33% of patients over 60 years old had a visual acuity of 20/200 or worse. The most severe visual acuity impairment (only being able to count fingers or worse) did not occur until the seventh decade of life. The same study found the mean rate of visual acuity loss to be about 0.09 [[logMAR chart|logMAR]] per 5 years, which is roughly 1 row on a [[Snellen chart]].<ref name = "Roberts"/>
==Diagnosis==
A diagnosis of choroideremia can be made based on family history, symptoms, and the characteristic appearance of the [[fundus (eye)|fundus]].<ref name = "Barnard"/> However, choroideremia shares several clinical features with [[retinitis pigmentosa]], a similar but broader group of retinal degenerative diseases, making a specific diagnosis difficult without genetic testing. Because of this choroideremia is often initially misdiagnosed as retinitis pigmentosa.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Guo|first1=Hui|last2=Li|first2=Jisheng|last3=Gao|first3=Fei|last4=Li|first4=Jiangxia|last5=Wu|first5=Xinyi|last6=Liu|first6=Qiji|title=Whole-exome sequencing reveals a novel CHM gene mutation in a family with choroideremia initially diagnosed as retinitis pigmentosa|journal=BMC Ophthalmology|date=28 July 2015|volume=15|issue=1|pages=85|doi=10.1186/s12886-015-0081-4|pmid=26216097|pmc=4517409}}</ref> A variety of different [[genetic testing|genetic testing techniques]] can be used to make a differential diagnosis.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sanchez-Alcudia|first1=Rocio|last2=Garcia-Hoyos|first2=Maria|last3=Lopez-Martinez|first3=Miguel Angel|last4=Sanchez-Bolivar|first4=Noelia|last5=Zurita|first5=Olga|last6=Gimenez|first6=Ascension|last7=Villaverde|first7=Cristina|last8=Rodrigues-Jacy da Silva|first8=Luciana|last9=Corton|first9=Marta|last10=Perez-Carro|first10=Raquel|last11=Torriano|first11=Simona|last12=Kalatzis|first12=Vasiliki|last13=Rivolta|first13=Carlo|last14=Avila-Fernandez|first14=Almudena|last15=Lorda|first15=Isabel|last16=Trujillo-Tiebas|first16=Maria J.|last17=Garcia-Sandoval|first17=Blanca|last18=Lopez-Molina|first18=Maria Isabel|last19=Blanco-Kelly|first19=Fiona|last20=Riveiro-Alvarez|first20=Rosa|last21=Ayuso|first21=Carmen|last22=Janecke|first22=Andreas R.|title=A Comprehensive Analysis of Choroideremia: From Genetic Characterization to Clinical Practice|journal=PLOS ONE|date=12 April 2016|volume=11|issue=4|pages=e0151943|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0151943|pmid=27070432|pmc=4829155}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Furgoch|first1=MJ|last2=Mewes-Arès|first2=J|last3=Radziwon|first3=A|last4=Macdonald|first4=IM|title=Molecular genetic diagnostic techniques in choroideremia.|journal=Molecular Vision|date=25 April 2014|volume=20|pages=535–44|pmid=24791138|pmc=4000712}}</ref>
==Management==
While nothing currently can be done to stop or reverse the retinal degeneration, there are steps that can be taken to slow the rate of vision loss. UV-blocking sunglasses for outdoors, appropriate dietary intake of fresh fruit and leafy green vegetables, antioxidant vitamin supplements, and regular intake of dietary omega-3 very-long-chain fatty acids are all recommended.<ref name = "GeneReviews"/> One study found that a dietary supplement of [[lutein]] increases [[Macula of retina|macular pigment]] levels in patients with choroideremia. Over a long period of time, these elevated levels of pigmentation could slow retinal degeneration.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Duncan|first1=JL|last2=Aleman|first2=TS|last3=Gardner|first3=LM|last4=De Castro|first4=E|last5=Marks|first5=DA|last6=Emmons|first6=JM|last7=Bieber|first7=ML|last8=Steinberg|first8=JD|last9=Bennett|first9=J|last10=Stone|first10=EM|last11=MacDonald|first11=IM|last12=Cideciyan|first12=AV|last13=Maguire|first13=MG|last14=Jacobson|first14=SG|title=Macular pigment and lutein supplementation in choroideremia.|journal=Experimental Eye Research|date=March 2002|volume=74|issue=3|pages=371–81|doi=10.1006/exer.2001.1126|pmid=12014918}}</ref> Additional interventions that may be needed include surgical correction of retinal detachment and cataracts, low vision services, and counseling to help cope with depression, loss of independence, and anxiety over job loss.<ref name = "GeneReviews"/>
===Gene therapy=== {{See also|Gene therapy of the human retina}} Gene therapy is currently not a treatment option, however human [[clinical trials]] for both choroideremia and [[Leber's congenital amaurosis]] (LCA) have produced somewhat promising results.<ref name=GhoshBBC11>Pallab Ghosh, 2011, "Health: Gene therapy used in a bid to save a man's sight," at ''BBC News'' (online), October 27, 2011, see [https://www.bbc.com/news/health-15446912], accessed 23 April 2015.</ref>
Clinical trials of gene therapy for patients with LCA began in 2008 at three different sites.<ref name="Cideciyan 2009">{{cite journal |author1=Cideciyan A. V. |author2=Hauswirth W. W. |author3=Aleman T. S. |author4=Kaushal S. |author5=Schwartz S. B. |author6=Boye S. L. |author7=Windsor E. A. M. | year = 2009 | title = Human RPE65 gene therapy for Leber congenital amaurosis: persistence of early visual improvements and safety at 1 year | url = | journal = Human Gene Therapy | volume = 20 | issue = 9| pages = 999–1004 | doi = 10.1089/hum.2009.086 | pmid=19583479 | pmc=2829287|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name="Simonelli 2010">{{cite journal |author1=Simonelli F. |author2=Maguire A. M. |author3=Testa F. |author4=Pierce E. A. |author5=Mingozzi F. |author6=Bennicelli J. M. |author2=High K. A. |author3=Auricchio A. |author4=Wright J. F. |author5=Pierce E. A. |author6=Testa F. |author7=Mingozzi F. | year = 2009 | title = Age-dependent effects of RPE65 gene therapy for Leber's congenital amaurosis: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial | journal = Lancet | volume = 374 | issue = 9701| pages = 1597–1605 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(09)61836-5 | pmid=19854499|display-authors=etal | pmc=4492302}}</ref><ref name="Bainbridge 2008">{{cite journal |author1=Bainbridge J. W. B. |author2=Smith A. J. |author3=Barker S. S. |author4=Robbie S. |author5=Henderson R. |author6=Balaggan K. |author7=Viswanathan A. | year = 2008 | title = Effect of gene therapy on visual function in Leber's congenital amaurosis | url = | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 358 | issue = 21| pages = 2231–2239 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMoa0802268 | pmid = 18441371 |display-authors=etal|citeseerx=10.1.1.574.4003 }}</ref> In general, these studies found the therapy to be safe, somewhat effective, and promising as a future treatment for similar retinal diseases.
In 2011, the first gene therapy treatment for choroideremia was administered.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=MacLaren|first1=RE|last2=Groppe|first2=M|last3=Barnard|first3=AR|last4=Cottriall|first4=CL|last5=Tolmachova|first5=T|last6=Seymour|first6=L|last7=Clark|first7=KR|last8=During|first8=MJ|last9=Cremers|first9=FP|last10=Black|first10=GC|last11=Lotery|first11=AJ|last12=Downes|first12=SM|last13=Webster|first13=AR|last14=Seabra|first14=MC|title=Retinal gene therapy in patients with choroideremia: initial findings from a phase 1/2 clinical trial.|journal=Lancet|date=29 March 2014|volume=383|issue=9923|pages=1129–37|pmid=24439297|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(13)62117-0|pmc=4171740}}</ref> The surgery was performed by [[Robert MacLaren]], Professor of Ophthalmology at the University of Oxford and leader of the Clinical Ophthalmology Research Group at the Nuffield Laboratory of Ophthalmology (NLO). <ref name=GhoshBBC11/><ref name=BeallNewSci14>Abigail Beall, 2014, "Gene therapy restores sight in people with eye disease," ''New Scientist'' (online), January 16, 2014, see [https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn24879-gene-therapy-restores-sight-in-people-with-eye-disease.html#.VTkaJTf_SOJ], accessed 23 April 2015.</ref><ref>Ewen Callaway, 2008, "Gene therapy success 'reverses' blindness," ''New Scientist'' (online), April 28, 2008, see [https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn13783-gene-therapy-success-reverses-blindness.html#.VTkaXDf_SOI] and [http://www.nature.com/news/2008/080428/full/news.2008.786.html] and [http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa0802315], accessed 23 April 2015.</ref> In the study, 2 doses of the [[adeno associated virus|AAV]].REP1 vector were injected subretinally in 12 patients with choroideremia. There study had 2 objectives: * to assess the safety and tolerability of the AAV.REP1 vector * to observe the therapeutic benefit, or slowing of the retinal degeneration, of the gene therapy during the study and at a 24-month post-treatment time point <ref>CT.gov, 2014, "Gene Therapy for Blindness Caused by Choroideremia (Sponsor:University of Oxford): NCT01461213," at ''ClinicalTrials.gov,'' see [https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01461213], accessed 23 April 2015.</ref> Despite retinal detachment caused by the injection, the study observed initial improved rod and cone function, warranting further study.
In 2016, researchers were optimistic that the positive results of 32 choroideremia patients treated over four and a half years with gene therapy in four countries could be long-lasting.<ref name="BBC2016">{{cite news|last1=Ghosh|first1=Pallab|title=Gene therapy reverses sight loss and is long-lasting|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-36101786|accessdate=29 April 2016|publisher=BBC News, Science & Environment|date=28 April 2016}}</ref>
===Preimplantation Genetic Diagnosis=== For women who carry a mutation in the CHM gene, [[preimplantation genetic diagnosis]] can be used during the [[in-vitro fertilization]] process to select unaffected embryos to implant.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://americanpregnancy.org/infertility/preimplantation-genetic-diagnosis/|title=Preimplantation Genetic Diagnosis: (PGD)|website=www.americanpregnancy.org|access-date=23 June 2018|date=2012-04-24}}</ref> This process call be applied to any [[genetic disorder|monogenic]] disease.
===Other potential therapies===
While choroideremia is an ideal candidate for gene therapy<ref name = "Roberts"/> there are other potential therapies that could restore vision after it has been lost later in life. Foremost of these is [[stem cell]] [[stem-cell therapy|therapy]]. A clinical trial published in 2014 found that a subretinal injection of [[human embryonic stem cells]] in patients with [[Macular degeneration|age-related macular degeneration]] and [[Stargardt disease]] was safe and improved vision in most patients. Out of 18 patients, vision improved in 10, improved or remained the same in 7, and decreased in 1 patient, while no improvement was seen in the untreated eyes. The study found "no evidence of adverse proliferation, rejection, or serious ocular or systemic safety issues related to the transplanted tissue."<ref name = "Schwartz">{{cite journal|last1=Schwartz|first1=SD|last2=Regillo|first2=CD|last3=Lam|first3=BL|last4=Eliott|first4=D|last5=Rosenfeld|first5=PJ|last6=Gregori|first6=NZ|last7=Hubschman|first7=JP|last8=Davis|first8=JL|last9=Heilwell|first9=G|last10=Spirn|first10=M|last11=Maguire|first11=J|last12=Gay|first12=R|last13=Bateman|first13=J|last14=Ostrick|first14=RM|last15=Morris|first15=D|last16=Vincent|first16=M|last17=Anglade|first17=E|last18=Del Priore|first18=LV|last19=Lanza|first19=R|title=Human embryonic stem cell-derived retinal pigment epithelium in patients with age-related macular degeneration and Stargardt's macular dystrophy: follow-up of two open-label phase 1/2 studies.|journal=Lancet|date=7 February 2015|volume=385|issue=9967|pages=509–16|pmid=25458728|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(14)61376-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Duffy|first1=Maureen|title=Updated Stem Cell Clinical Trial Results for Stargardt Disease and Dry Macular Degeneration - VisionAware Blog - VisionAware|url=http://www.visionaware.org/blog/visionaware-blog/positive-stem-cell-clinical-trial-results-for-stargardt-disease-and-dry-macular-degeneration-1588/12|website=www.visionaware.org|accessdate=23 January 2017|language=en}}</ref> A 2015 study used [[CRISPR#Genome engineering|CRISPR/Cas9]] to repair mutations in patient-derived [[induced pluripotent stem cells]] that cause X-linked retinitis pigmentosa.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bassuk|first1=Alexander G.|last2=Zheng|first2=Andrew|last3=Li|first3=Yao|last4=Tsang|first4=Stephen H.|last5=Mahajan|first5=Vinit B.|title=Precision Medicine: Genetic Repair of Retinitis Pigmentosa in Patient-Derived Stem Cells|journal=Scientific Reports|date=27 January 2016|volume=6|pages=19969|doi=10.1038/srep19969|pmid=26814166|pmc=4728485}}</ref> This study suggests that a patient's own repaired cells could be used for therapy, reducing the risk of immune rejection and [[Stem cell controversy|ethical issues]] that come with the use of embryonic stem cells.
==Research==
===History===
Choroideremia was first described in 1872 by an Austrian ophthalmologist, [[Ludwig Mauthner]].<ref name= "Barnard">{{cite journal|last1=Barnard|first1=A. R.|last2=Groppe|first2=M.|last3=MacLaren|first3=R. E.|title=Gene Therapy for Choroideremia Using an Adeno-Associated Viral (AAV) Vector|journal=Cold Spring Harbor Perspectives in Medicine|date=30 October 2014|volume=5|issue=3|pages=a017293|doi=10.1101/cshperspect.a017293|pmid=25359548|pmc=4355255}}</ref> Initially the condition was thought to be a developmental disorder which caused the absence of a majority of the choroid (hence the probable use of the ancient Greek suffix “eremia,” meaning barren land or desert).<ref name = "Barnard" /> After several decades the non-progressive nature of the disease was questioned, eventually being rejected by Paymerer et al. in 1960.<ref name = "Barnard" /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pameyer|first1=J. K.|last2=Waardenburg|first2=P. J.|last3=Henkes|first3=H. E.|title=CHOROIDEREMIA|journal=The British Journal of Ophthalmology|date=1 December 1960|volume=44|issue=12|pages=724–738|pmc=510030|issn=0007-1161|doi=10.1136/bjo.44.12.724|pmid=13732369}}</ref> The ''CHM'' gene was identified and cloned in 1990 by Frans P.M. Cremers.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cremers|first1=Frans P. M.|last2=van de Pol|first2=Dorien J. R.|last3=van Kerkhoff|first3=Liesbeth P. M.|last4=Wieringa|first4=Berend|last5=Ropers|first5=Hans-Hilger|title=Cloning of a gene that is rearranged in patients with choroideraemia|journal=Nature|date=18 October 1990|volume=347|issue=6294|pages=674–677|doi=10.1038/347674a0|pmid=2215697}}</ref>
===Basic research===
In many inherited retinal diseases the protein affected by the mutation is directly involved in the light sensing function of the eye, however this is not the case in choroideremia.<ref name = "Barnard" /> REP1 assists the [[prenylation]] of Rab G-proteins by binding and presenting them to the [[Rab geranylgeranyltransferase|Rab geranylgeranyltransferase subunit]].<ref name = "Pylypenko">{{cite journal|last1=Pylypenko|first1=O|last2=Rak|first2=A|last3=Reents|first3=R|last4=Niculae|first4=A|last5=Sidorovitch|first5=V|last6=Cioaca|first6=MD|last7=Bessolitsyna|first7=E|last8=Thomä|first8=NH|last9=Waldmann|first9=H|last10=Schlichting|first10=I|last11=Goody|first11=RS|last12=Alexandrov|first12=K|title=Structure of Rab escort protein-1 in complex with Rab geranylgeranyltransferase.|journal=Molecular Cell|date=February 2003|volume=11|issue=2|pages=483–94|pmid=12620235|doi=10.1016/s1097-2765(03)00044-3}}</ref> REP1 also escorts prenylated Rabs through the cytoplasm by binding the [[hydrophobic]] [[prenyl]] groups and carrying them to a specific destination membrane.<ref name = "Pylypenko" />
In healthy individuals, REP1 is found throughout all of the cells of the body, however patients with choroideremia only experience vision loss, and not broader, systemic symptoms (with the exception of a study that found crystals and [[fatty acid]] abnormalities in [[leukocytes]]).<ref name=Zhang2015>{{cite journal | author = Zhang AY, Mysore N, Vali H, Koenekoop J, Cao SN, Li S, Ren H, Keser V, Lopez-Solache I, Siddiqui SN, Khan A, Mui J, Sears K, Dixon J, Schwartzentruber J, Majewski J, Braverman N, Koenekoop RK | year = 2015 | title = Choroideremia is a systemic disease With lymphocyte crystals and plasma lipid and RBC membrane abnormalities | url = | journal = Invest Ophthalmol Vis Sci | volume = 56 | issue = 13| pages = 8158–8165 | doi = 10.1167/iovs.14-15751 | pmid = 26720468 | pmc = 4699407 }}</ref> REP2, a protein that is 75% identical and 90% [[similarity measure|similar]] to REP1, is able to significantly compensate for the loss of REP1 outside the eye.<ref name = "Barnard"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cremers|first1=FP|last2=Armstrong|first2=SA|last3=Seabra|first3=MC|last4=Brown|first4=MS|last5=Goldstein|first5=JL|title=REP-2, a Rab escort protein encoded by the choroideremia-like gene.|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|date=21 January 1994|volume=269|issue=3|pages=2111–7|pmid=8294464}}</ref> It is thought that REP2 is not able to fully compensate for the loss of REP1 in the retina.<ref name = "Barnard"/> [[RAB27A]], a Rab that has essential functions in the retina,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tolmachova|first1=T|last2=Ramalho|first2=JS|last3=Anant|first3=JS|last4=Schultz|first4=RA|last5=Huxley|first5=CM|last6=Seabra|first6=MC|title=Cloning, mapping and characterization of the human RAB27A gene.|journal=Gene|date=18 October 1999|volume=239|issue=1|pages=109–16|pmid=10571040|doi=10.1016/s0378-1119(99)00371-6}}</ref> has been shown to be preferentially prenylated by REP1.<ref name = "Larijani">{{cite journal|last1=Larijani|first1=B|last2=Hume|first2=AN|last3=Tarafder|first3=AK|last4=Seabra|first4=MC|title=Multiple factors contribute to inefficient prenylation of Rab27a in Rab prenylation diseases.|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|date=21 November 2003|volume=278|issue=47|pages=46798–804|pmid=12941939|doi=10.1074/jbc.m307799200}}</ref> Additionally, the Rab27a-REP1 and Rab27a-REP2 [[Multiprotein complex|complexes]] have different [[Ligand (biochemistry)#Receptor.2Fligand binding affinity|affinities]] for the Rab geranylgeranyltransferase enzyme, possibly explaining REP2's inability to fully compensate for REP1 in the retina.<ref name = "Larijani"/>
==Celebrities afflicted== A number of individuals in public roles are afflicted by choroidermia, and some have been involved in fundraising efforts for the disease. The former [[UK Labour Party|UK Labour]] [[Member of Parliament]] [[Siôn Simon]] is a known sufferer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/2053428.stm|title=BBC NEWS {{!}} UK {{!}} Politics {{!}} Sion Simon|website=news.bbc.co.uk|access-date=2017-01-20|date=2002-10-21}}</ref> Comic and activist E.J. Scott, partner of ''[[Daredevil (TV series)|Daredevil]]'' actress [[Deborah Ann Woll]], also suffers from the disease and is involved in regular fundraising efforts.<ref>Bill Dwyre, 2013, "Though going blind, E.J. Scott keeps looking ahead, moving forward," ''L.A. Times'' (online), January 11, 2013, see [http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jan/11/sports/la-sp-dwyre-20130112], accessed 23 April 2015.</ref><ref>E.J. Scott, 2015, "This is my 40: Running 7 continents in 1 year, blindfolded," at ''Crowdrise'' (online crowdsourcing), undated, see [https://www.crowdrise.com/ThisisMY40/fundraiser/ejscott], accessed 23 April 2015.</ref>
==Organizations==
There are a few organizations that provide support for individuals with choroideremia and raise money for research. They include: * [[Foundation Fighting Blindness|The Foundation Fighting Blindness]], which supports choroideremia among many other eye diseases [http://www.blindness.org/eye-conditions/choroideremia FFB website] * The Choroideremia Research Foundation [http://curechm.org/ (website)]

==Further reading== * Danny Boren, 2015, "First U.S. Gene Therapy Clinical Trial to treat Choroideremia initiated in Philadelphia," ''Choroideremia Research Foundation'' (online), Press Release Summary, January 20, 2015, see [http://curechm.org/first-u-s-gene-therapy-clinical-trial-to-treat-choroideremia-initiated-in-philadelphia/], accessed 23 April 2015. * Cory MacDonald, 2015, "Nightstar Receives U.S. and European Orphan Drug Designation for Gene Therapy to Treat Choroideremia," ''Choroideremia Research Foundation'' (online), Press Release Summary, March 24, 2015 (release date, January 11), see [https://archive.is/20150423172204/http://curechm.org/nightstar-receives-u-s-and-european-orphan-drug-designation-for-gene-therapy-to-treat-choroideremia/], accessed 23 April 2015. * FFB, 2015, "U.S. Human Study for Choroideremia Gene Therapy Launched by Spark Therapeutics," ''Foundation Fighting Blindness'' (online), January 27, 2015, see [http://www.blindness.org/foundation-news/us-human-study-choroideremia-gene-therapy-launched-spark-therapeutics], accessed 23 April 2015. * NLO, 2014, "First Results of Choroideremia Gene Therapy Trial (2014)," ''Nuffield Laboratory of Ophthalmology'' (online), Press Release, undated, see [https://web.archive.org/web/20150403143914/http://www.eye.ox.ac.uk/research/clinical-ophthalmology-research-group/press-releases/first-results-of-choroideremia-gene-therapy-trial-2014], accessed 23 April 2015.

{{lead rewrite|date=May 2016}} '''Codex Alimentarius Austriacus''' is a collection of standards and product descriptions for a variety of foods, established by the Austrian-Hungarian Empire in October 1891. <ref>[ftp://ftp.fao.org/codex/Publications/understanding/Understanding_EN.pdf Understanding The Codex Alimentarius (Third Edition)]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Published by the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] of the [[United Nations]] and the [[World Health Organization]], 2006. Accessed 4 January 2008.</ref> The Codex Alimentarius Austriacus standards is primarily the product of a voluntary effort of experts in the food industry and universities. While the standards laid out in the codex were not legally enforceable, they were nonetheless used by the courts to determine the identity and quality of a variety of food products.<ref name="codex">Randell, A. [http://www.fao.org/docrep/v7700t/v7700t09.htm Codex Alimentarius: how it all began]. [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] of the [[United Nations]] website. Accessed 1 January 2009.</ref>{{food safety}} == History ==
Until the Mid 20th Century, the Codex Alimentarius Austriacus was not well-known beyond the German-speaking countries of Europe. It subsequently lent its name to the international [[Codex Alimentarius]] Commission, the current international food codex collaboratively worked out by the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] and the [[World Health Organization]].<ref name="codex" /> Consisting of three volumes, the [[Codex]] was finished sometime between 1910–1917 by [[O. Dafert]]. It lacked actual integration into Austrian law until 1975.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} The idea of a Europe-wide Codex Alimentarius based on the Austrian model was actively pursued by Hans Frenzel of Austria between 1954 and 1958. Frenzel's work culminated in the creation of the Council of the [[Codex Alimentarius Europaeus]] in June 1958, under the joint sponsorship of the International Commission on Agricultural Industries and the International Bureau of [[Analytical Chemistry]].<ref name="codex" /> In 1975, the committee for the Codex Alimentarius Austriacus was reorganized to conform with [[Austria]]n food laws, which have a reputation of being some of the strictest food laws in the world.<ref>http://www.geneticallymodifiedfoods.co.uk/austria-gm-food-bans.html</ref>
== See also == * [[Codex Alimentarius]]

The '''Compensation scheme for radiation-linked diseases''' is a workers compensation scheme administered by the [[Government of the United Kingdom|UK government]]. It was established in November 1982 by [[British Nuclear Fuels Ltd|British Nuclear Fuels Limited]] and its [[Trade union|trade unions]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=shCh5KzE7xEC&pg=PA20&lpg=PA20&dq=%22compensation+scheme+for+radiation+linked+diseases%22&source=bl&ots=ay7uRDDnnA&sig=bHI_Fkk4rUc8nrJO_z454mgC10E&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjj6uWFjcPRAhUBTJQKHeIbBFkQ6AEIRDAI#v=onepage&q=%22compensation%20scheme%20for%20radiation%20linked%20diseases%22&f=false|title=The Redfern Inquiry into human tissue analysis in UK nuclear facilities|last=|first=|date=2010-11-16|publisher=The Stationery Office|year=|isbn=9780102966183|location=|pages=|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> following legal actions brought against the company by nuclear industry workers in the late 1970s. At the time of its establishment, BNFL and its trade unions agreed that the causation of cancer by radiation was sufficiently well understood that "it should be possible to construct a scheme which would evaluate the probability that a diagnosed cancer may have been caused by radiation exposure at work." Initially the scheme only accepted claims in which a worker had died from a radiation-linked disease. In 1987 this was expanded to allow [[Disease|morbidity]] claims.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.csrld.org.uk/html/scheme_history.php|title=CSRLD: The Compensation Scheme for Radiation Linked Diseases - Scheme history|last=|first=|date=|website=www.csrld.org.uk|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-26}}</ref> The list of participating member employers and trade unions has grown through the 1990s and 2000s. As of December 2015, 1525 claims have been made out of which 156 have been successful.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.csrld.org.uk/html/annual_statement.php|title=CSRLD: 2015 Compensation Scheme Annual Statement|last=|first=|date=2015-12-01|website=www.csrld.org.uk|publisher=Government of the United Kingdom|access-date=2016-09-26}}</ref>
== Eligibility == In order to be eligible for compensation, a worker must have been employed by a listed company, and have received an occupational radiation dose. Then the claimant must have developed [[cancer]] of the [[Bladder cancer|bladder]], [[Bone Cancer|bone]], [[Brain cancer|brain]] and central nervous system, [[Breast cancer|breast]] or [[Uterine cancer|uterus]] (for female workers), [[Colorectal cancer|colon]], [[Liver cancer|liver]], [[Esophageal cancer|oesophagus]], respiratory or [[Lung cancer|lung]], prostate, [[Ovarian cancer|ovary]], skin (non-Melanoma), [[Thyroid cancer|thyroid]] or other tissues. Other compensable diseases include [[Cataract|cataracts]] and [[Leukemia|leukaemias]] (with two exceptions). Some diseases are excluded on the basis that there is no convincing epidemiological evidence to link them with ionising radiation exposure. Excluded diseases include: [[Hodgkin's lymphoma|Hodgkin’s disease]], [[Hairy cell leukemia|hairy cell leukaemia]], [[Chronic lymphatic leukemia|chronic lymphatic leukaemia]] (CLL), [[Melanoma|malignant melanoma]] and [[mesothelioma]].
=== Eligible employers === {| class="wikitable" !Member !Year joined |- |British Nuclear Fuels Limited |1982 |- |[[United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority]] (UKAEA) |1987 |- |[[Urenco Group|URENCO UK Limited]] |1993 |- |[[Magnox Electric]] |1993 |- |[[Nuclear Electric]] |1993 |- |[[Scottish Nuclear|Scottish Nuclear Limited]] (SNL) |1993 |- |[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] |1994 |- |[[Atomic Weapons Establishment]] (AWE) |1994 |- |[[Devonport Royal Dockyard|Devonport Royal Dockyard Ltd]] (DRDL) |1997 |- |Rosyth Royal Dockyard Ltd (RRD) |1997 |- |Babcock Naval Services |2005 |- |[[GE Healthcare]] |2005 |- |[[EDF Energy|EDF Energy Nuclear Generation Ltd]] (formerly British Energy Generation Ltd) | |- |Springfields Fuels Limited | |- |[[Low Level Waste Repository|LLW Repository Ltd]] (formerly Drigg) | |- |Dounreay Site Restoration Ltd (DSRL) | |- |Research Sites Restoration Ltd (RSRL) | |}
=== Member Trade Unions === In 1982, trade union members of the scheme included [[Transport and General Workers' Union|Transport and General Workers Union]], [[Institution of Professional Civil Servants]], [[Amalgamated Engineering Union]], [[GMB (trade union)|GMB]] and PCS. Other trades unions joined as the scheme expanded. Later members include the [[Electrical, Electronic, Telecommunications and Plumbing Union|EETPU]] and [[Manufacturing Science Finance|MSF]], [[Union of Construction, Allied Trades and Technicians|UCATT]], [[Engineers and Managers Association]], [[UNISON|Unison]], the [[First Division Association]] of Civil Servants, the AEA Constabulary Federation (now the Civil Nuclear Police Federation) and the [[Defence Police Federation]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csrld.org.uk/html/scheme_employers.php|title=CSRLD: The Compensation Scheme for Radiation Linked Diseases - Scheme employers|last=|first=|date=|website=www.csrld.org.uk|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-26}}</ref>
== Claiming compensation == Claims may be lodged by the worker, his or her wife, husband or partner (including same sex), the worker's "first line children" (those born to or legally adopted by the claimant). Once diagnosed with or deceased from an eligible disease, the worker or surviving family members have 30 years in which to make a claim. Claims can be made online, by post, by phone or through the worker's trade union. Once made, claims are assessed on consideration of medical, employment and dosimetry histories and data. These are used to calculate the probability that the cancer could have been caused by occupational exposure to radiation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csrld.org.uk/html/qa.php|title=CSRLD: The Compensation Scheme for Radiation Linked Diseases - Q & A|last=|first=|date=|website=www.csrld.org.uk|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-26}}</ref>
== Payments == The payment received following a successful claim varies depending on the actual loss (in earnings and pension) suffered by the claimant and sums for pain and suffering, loss of amenity and number of dependents. The level of payment awarded to a claimant (or estate if deceased) is determined by the "causation probability". The greater the causation probability, the greater the payment. Top tier payments are awarded if the causation probability is 50% or more. The Scheme publishes an Annual statement which is approved by the Scheme Council. The report includes a paragraph updating the number of claims and payments awarded.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csrld.org.uk/html/case_processing.php|title=CSRLD: The Compensation Scheme for Radiation Linked Diseases - Case Processing|last=|first=|date=|website=www.csrld.org.uk|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-26}}</ref>
By 22 February 2005, 1000 claims had been made, of which 97 had been awarded to varying degrees along a sliding scale.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=oxqdAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT152&lpg=PT152&dq=%22compensation+scheme+for+radiation+linked+diseases%22&source=bl&ots=sCtN2E6adQ&sig=0MUeAJ5xKrJx-EFVDn_13BMYhEI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjj6uWFjcPRAhUBTJQKHeIbBFkQ6AEIRzAJ#v=onepage&q=%22compensation%20scheme%20for%20radiation%20linked%20diseases%22&f=false|title=Assessment of the Scientific Information for the Radiation Exposure Screening and Education Program|last=|first=|last2=|first2=|last3=|first3=|last4=|first4=|date=2005-10-01|publisher=National Academies Press|year=|isbn=9780309096102|location=|pages=137|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref>
As of December 2015, 1525 cases had been considered since the compensation scheme for radiation-linked diseases was established. 156 of these claims were successful, and payments totaling £8.24 million had been dispatched.<ref name=":1" />
== References == <references />

{{Infobox Officeholder |honorific-prefix = [[Major]] |name = Courage Quashigah |honorific-suffix = |image = |imagesize = |smallimage = |alt = |caption = |order = |office = Minister for Health |term_start = January 2005 |term_end = January 2009 |president = [[John Kufuor]] |predecessor = Dr. Kwaku Afriyie |successor = Dr. George Sipa-Adjah Yankey |order2 = |office2 = Minister for Agriculture |term_start2 = January 2001 |term_end2 = January 2005 |president2 = [[John Kufuor]] |predecessor2 = Ibrahim Issaka Adam |successor2 = [[Ernest Debrah|Ernest Akubuor Debrah]] |constituency2 = |majority2 = |birth_date = 9 September 1947 |birth_place = Kedzi, [[Ghana]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2010|01|05|1947|09|09|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Israel]] |restingplace = |restingplacecoordinates = |birthname = |nationality = [[Ghanaian]] |party = [[New Patriotic Party]] |otherparty = |spouse = |partner = |relations = |children = |residence = |alma_mater = |occupation = Politician |profession = Army officer |cabinet = |committees = |portfolio = |religion = |signature = |signature_alt= |website = |footnotes = |nickname = |allegiance = Ghana |branch = [[Ghana army]] |serviceyears = |rank = [[Major]] |unit = |commands = |battles = |awards = |military_blank1 = |military_data1 = |military_blank2 = |military_data2 = |military_blank3 = |military_data3 = |military_blank4 = |military_data4 = |military_blank5 = |military_data5 = }} [[Major]] '''Courage Emmanuel Kobla Quashigah''' (9 September 1947 – 5 January 2010) was a [[Ghanaian]] [[soldier]] and [[politician]]. He held many prominent positions in the [[Ghana Armed Forces]] and was a [[Minister of State]] for Agriculture and later Health in the [[Kufuor government|NPP government]] of [[John Kufuor]] between 2001 and 2009. ==Early life and education== Quashigah was born at Kedzi in the [[Volta Region]] of [[Ghana]]. He had his secondary and sixth form education at the [[Keta Secondary School]] also in the Volta Region. He gained his [[GCE Ordinary Level]] and [[GCE Advanced Level]] certificates there. He proceeded to the [[United Kingdom]] where he studied at the [[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst|Royal Military Academy]] at [[Sandhurst, Berkshire|Sandhurst]]. He qualified with a Diploma in [[Economics]], [[War studies]] and [[Communication studies]]. He was awarded the Cane and Certificate of Honour as Best Overseas Cadet and Highest in the Order of Merit at Sandhurst. ==Military career== Quashigah served as an Intelligence officer at the headquarters of the Second Infantry Brigade of the [[Ghana Army]] based at [[Kumasi]] in the [[Ashanti Region]] of Ghana. He then became the Chief Instructor at the Jungle Warfare School at Akyease, in the Eastern Region. Other positions later held by him include Commanding Officer of the Ghana Military Police and Commanding Officer of the Forces Reserve Battalion. He has also served as a Director at the Military Academy and Training School at [[Teshie]], a suburb of [[Accra]]. Quashigah distinguished himself in various fields in the army. After serving with the [[United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon]], he won a Commendation for Efficient and Effective Command. ==Politics== During the military rule of the [[Provisional National Defence Council]] (PNDC), he was the Chief Operations Officer at the (PNDC) Headquarters, Gondar Barracks, Burma Camp, Accra. He has also served as a Member of the Police Council of Ghana. Quashigah was formerly a close ally of [[Jerry Rawlings]], [[Head of state of Ghana]] and chairman of the PNDC.{{cite web |url=http://www.country-studies.com/ghana/charting-the-political-transition.html |title=Country studies: Charting the Political Transition |accessdate=2010-01-06 |publisher=Federal Research Division of the Library of Congress}} On September 24, 1989, Quashigah and four others were arrested for allegedly plotting to overthrow the PNDC government.{{cite web |url=http://www.photius.com/countries/ghana/national_security/ghana_national_security_the_1981_coup_and_th~152.html |title=The 1981 Coup and the Second Rawlings Government |accessdate=2010-01-06 |work=Ghana National Security profile |publisher=www.theodora.com}} He was finally released in 1992.{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/NWS11/013/1992/en |title=WEEKLY UPDATE SERVICE 13/92 (INCLUDES ADDITION) |accessdate=2010-01-06 |date=1 April 1992 |work= |publisher=[[Amnesty International]]}} In 1998, he became the national organiser of the [[New Patriotic Party]] (NPP).{{cite news |url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=174683 |title=Quashigah is dead |accessdate=2010-01-06 |work=General News of Tuesday, 5 January 2010 |publisher=Ghana Home Page}} After the NPP formed a government in January 2001, Quashigah was appointed Minister of Agriculture.{{cite news |url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=13359 |title= Eleven Ministers Sworn-in |accessdate=2010-01-06 |work=General News of Friday, 2 February 2001 |publisher=Ghana Home Page}} He was appointed Health Minister after a cabinet reshuffle in 2005 after President Kufuor had been reelected in the December 2000 presidential election.{{cite news |url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=74556 |title=Twenty-nine Ministers sworn into office |accessdate=2010-01-06 |work=General News of Wednesday, 2 February 2005 |publisher=Ghana Home Page}} Whilst serving as minister of Health, Quashigah received notable recognition
for outstanding and exceptional contribution towards initiating a national health education on healthy lifestyle living and nutrition in Ghana and his efforts has grandly become extremely successful since the Africa Union has called on member states to declare the last Friday of each year as Africa's Healthy Lifestyles Day. Subsequently Ghana has named Ghana's Former Minister for Health, Major Quashigah, FGNAHAF as Africa's Best Health Minister in recent times and Ghanaians should be proud.http://www.modernghana.com/news/210255/1/ghanas-former-minister-major-quashigah-named-for-a.html
==Death== Quashigah traveled to Israel during a short illness for some public engagements and to seek medical attention but died during his trip.{{cite news |url=http://www.graphicghana.com/news/page.php?news=5918 |title=Courage Quashigah Is Dead |accessdate=2010-01-07|work= |publisher=Daily Graphic Online}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External sources== *[http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/people/pop-up.php?ID=181 Profile on Ghanaweb.com] *[http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=174683 Quashigah's death on Ghanaweb.com] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=Dr. Kwaku Afriyie}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Kufuor government|Minister for Health]]|years=2005–2009}} {{s-aft|after=[[George Yankey|Dr. George Sipa-Adjah Yankey]]}} {{s-bef|before=Ibrahim Issaka Adam}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Kufuor government|Minister for Agriculture]]|years=2001–2005}} {{s-aft|after=[[Ernest Debrah]]}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Quashigah, Courage}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Ghanaian soldiers]] [[Category:Ghanaian military personnel]] [[Category:Graduates of the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst]] [[Category:Agriculture ministers of Ghana]] [[Category:Health ministers of Ghana]] [[Category:New Patriotic Party politicians]]
