'''Dichotic listening''' or the '''Dichotic listening test''' is a psychological test commonly used to investigate [[selective attention]] within the [[auditory system]] and is a subtopic of [[cognitive psychology]] and [[neuroscience]]. Specifically, it is "used as a behavioral test for hemispheric lateralization of speech sound perception."<ref name=Ingram2007>{{cite book|last=Ingram|first=John C.L.|title=Neurolinguistics: an introduction to spoken language processing and its disorders|year=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=978-0-521-79640-8|edition=1. publ., 3. print.}}</ref>{{rp|381}} During a standard dichotic listening test, a participant is presented with two different auditory stimuli simultaneously (usually [[Speech communication|speech]]). The different stimuli are directed into different ears over headphones.<ref name=Ingram2007/>{{Page needed|date=November 2016}} Participants are asked to pay attention to one or both of the stimuli. Later, they are asked about the content of either the message they were asked to attend to or the message that they were not told to listen to. As a result of focusing to repeat the words, participants noticed little of the message to the other ear, often not even realizing that at some point it changed from English to German. At the same time, participants did notice when the voice in the unattended ear changed from a male's to a female's, suggesting that the selectivity of consciousness can work to tune in some information."<ref>{{cite book|last= Schacter, GILBERT, WEGNER|first=Daniel|title=Psychology|year=2011|publisher=WorthPublishers|location=Cambridge|isbn=978-1-429-24107-6|pages=180|edition=1. publ., 3. print.}}</ref>
Dichotic listening also relates to the third basic property of consciousness: [[Selective auditory attention|Selectivity]] which is the capacity to include some objects but not others.<ref name="Schacter 2010">{{cite book |author=Schacter, Daniel L |title=Psychology |publisher=Worth Publishers |location=New York |year=2010 |pages= |isbn=1-4292-3719-8 |oclc= 696604625}}</ref>
==History== In the late 1960s and early 1970s Donald Shankweiler<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.haskins.yale.edu/staff/shankweiler.html |title=Donald P. Shankweiler}}</ref> and [[Michael Studdert-Kennedy]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.haskins.yale.edu/staff/msk.html |title=Michael Studdert-Kennedy }}</ref> of [[Haskins Laboratories]] used a dichotic listening technique (presenting different nonsense syllables) to demonstrate the dissociation of [[phonetic]] (speech) and [[sound|auditory]] (nonspeech) perception by finding that phonetic structure devoid of meaning is an integral part of language and is typically processed in the left [[cerebral hemisphere]].<ref name=Studdert-Kennedy(a)> {{cite journal |last1=Studdert-Kennedy |first1=Michael |last2=Shankweiler |first2=Donald |date=19 August 1970 |title=Hemispheric specialization for speech perception |journal=Journal of the Acoustical Society of America |volume=48 |issue=2 |pages=579–594 |doi=10.1121/1.1912174}}</ref><ref name=Studdert-Kennedy(b)>{{cite journal |author1=Studdert-Kennedy M. |author2=Shankweiler D. |author3=Schulman S. | year = 1970 | title = Opposed effects of a delayed channel on perception of dichotically and monotically presented CV syllables | url = | journal = Journal of the Acoustical Society of America | volume = 48 | issue = | pages = 599–602 | doi=10.1121/1.1912179}}</ref><ref name=Studdert-Kennedy(c)>{{cite journal |author1=Studdert-Kennedy M. |author2=Shankweiler D. |author3=Pisoni D. | year = 1972 | title = Auditory and phonetic processes in speech perception: Evidence from a dichotic study | url = | journal = Journal of Cognitive Psychology | volume = 2 | issue = | pages = 455–466 |doi=10.1016/0010-0285(72)90017-5 |pmc=3523680 }}</ref> A dichotic listening performance advantage for one ear is interpreted as indicating a processing advantage in the contralateral [[cerebral hemisphere|hemisphere]]. In another example, Sidtis (1981)<ref name=Sidtis>{{cite journal | author = Sidtis J. J. | year = 1981 | title = The complex tone test: Implications for the assessment of auditory laterality effects | url = | journal = Neuropsychologia | volume = 19 | issue = | pages = 103–112 | doi=10.1016/0028-3932(81)90050-6}}</ref> found that healthy adults have a left-ear advantage on a dichotic pitch recognition experiment. He interpreted this result as indicating right-hemisphere dominance for pitch discrimination.
During the early 1970s, Tim Rand demonstrated dichotic perception at [[Haskins Laboratories]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.haskins.yale.edu/publications/pub-r.html |title=Rand, T. C. (1974) |work=Haskins Laboratories Publications-R |accessdate=}}</ref><ref name=Rand>{{cite journal |last=Rand |first=Timothy C. | year = 1974 | title = Dichotic release from masking for speech | url = | journal = Journal of the Acoustical Society of America | volume = 55 | issue = 3| pages = 678–680 | doi=10.1121/1.1914584 | pmid=4819869}}</ref> In his study, the first stimuli: [[formant]] (F1), was presented to one ear while the second and third stimuli:(F2) and (F3) formants, were presented to the opposite ear. F2 and F3 varied in low and high intensity. Ultimately, in comparison to the binaural condition, "peripheral masking is avoided when speech is heard dichotically."<ref name=Rand /> This demonstration was originally known as "the Rand effect" but was later renamed "dichotic release from masking". The name for this demonstration continued to evolve and was finally named "dichotic perception" or "dichotic listening." Around the same time, Jim Cutting (1976),<ref name=Cutting>{{cite journal | author = Cutting J. E. | year = 1976 | title = Auditory and linguistic processes in speech perception: inferences from six fusions in dichotic listening | url = | journal = Psychological Review | volume = 83 | issue = | pages = 114–140 | doi=10.1037/0033-295x.83.2.114}}</ref> an investigator at [[Haskins Laboratories]], researched how listeners could correctly identify syllables when different components of the syllable were presented to different ears. The [[formant]]s of vowel sounds and their relation are crucial in differentiating vowel sounds. Even though the listeners heard two separate signals with neither ear receiving a 'complete' vowel sound, they could still identify the syllable sounds.
==Dichotic listening test designs==
===Dichotic fused words test (DFWT)=== The "dichotic fused words test" (DFWT) is a modified version of the basic dichotic listening test. It was originally explored by Johnson ''et al.'' (1977)<ref>{{cite journal|last=Johnson|title=Dichotic ear preference in aphasia|journal=J. Speech Hear Res|year=1977|volume=20|pages=116–129|doi=10.1044/jshr.2001.116|pmid=846195|issue=1|display-authors=etal}}</ref> but in the early 80's Wexler and Hawles (1983)<ref name="Wexler 1983">{{cite journal|last=Wexler|first=Bruce|author2=Terry Hawles|title=Increasing the power of dichotic methods: the fused rhymed words test|journal=Neuropsychologia|year=1983|volume=21|doi=10.1016/0028-3932(83)90100-8|pmid=6843817|issue=1|pages=59–66}}</ref> modified this original test to ascertain more accurate data pertaining to hemispheric specialization of language function. In the DFWT, each participant listens to pairs of monosyllabic rhyming consonant-vowel-consonant (CVC) words. Each word varies in the initial consonant. The significant difference in this test is "the stimuli are constructed and aligned in such a way that partial interaural fusion occurs: subjects generally experience and report only one stimulus per trial."<ref name="Zatorre 1989">{{cite journal|last=Zatorre|first=Robert|title=Perceptual asymmetry on the dichotic fused words test and cerebral speech lateralization determined by the caroid sodium amytal test|journal=Neuropsychologia|year=1989|volume=27|issue=10|doi=10.1016/0028-3932(89)90033-x|pages=1207–1219|pmid=2480551}}</ref> According to Zatorre (1989), some major advantages of this method include "minimizing attentional factors, since the percept is unitary and localized to the midline" and "stimulus dominance effects may be explicitly calculated, and their influence on ear asymmetries assessed and eliminated."<ref name="Zatorre 1989"/> Wexler and Hawles study obtained a high test-retest reliability (r=0.85).<ref name="Wexler 1983"/> High test-retest reliability is good, because it proves that the data collected from the study is consistent.
===Testing with emotional factors=== An emotional version of the dichotic listening task was developed. In this version individuals listen to the same word in each ear but they hear it in either a surprised, happy, sad, angry, or neutral tone. Participants are then asked to press a button indicating what tone they heard. Usually dichotic listening tests show a right-ear advantage for speech sounds. Right-ear/left-hemisphere advantage is expected, because of evidence from [[Broca's area]] and [[Wernicke's area]], which are both located in the left hemisphere. In contrast, the left ear (and therefore the right hemisphere) is often better at processing nonlinguistic material.<ref name="Grimshaw 2003">{{cite journal|last=Grimshaw|journal=Neuropsychologia|year=2003|volume=41|doi=10.1016/s0028-3932(02)00315-9 |display-authors=etal|title=The dynamic nature of language lateralization: effects of lexical and prosodic factors|pages=1008–1019|pmid=12667536}}</ref> The data from the emotional dichotic listening task is consistent with the other studies, because participants tend to have more correct responses to their left ear than to the right.<ref name="Hahn 2011">{{cite journal|last=Hahn|first=Constanze|title=Smoking reduces language lateralization: A dichotic listening study with control participants and schizophrenia patients|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0278262611000625|work=Journal|doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2011.03.015|volume=76|pages=300–309|pmid=21524559|date=Jul 2011}}</ref> It is important to note that the emotional dichotic listening task is seemingly harder for the participants than the phonemic dichotic listening task. Meaning more incorrect responses were submitted by individuals.
===Manipulation of voice onset time (VOT)=== The manipulation of voice onset time (VOT) during dichotic listening tests have given many insights regarding brain function.<ref name="Arciuli 2011">{{cite journal |author=Arciuli J |title=Manipulation of voice onset time during dichotic listening |journal=Brain Cogn |volume=76 |issue=2 |pages=233–8 |date=July 2011 |pmid=21320740 |doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2011.01.007 |url=}}</ref> To date, the most common design is the utilisation of four VOT conditions: short-long pairs (SL), where a Consonant-Vowel (CV) syllable with a short VOT is presented to the left ear and a CV syllable with a long VOT is presented to the right ear, as well as long-short (LS), short-short (SS) and long-long (LL) pairs. In 2006, Rimol, Eichele, and Hugdahl<ref name="Rimol 2006">{{cite journal|author1=Rimol, L.M. |author2=Eichele, T. |author3=Hugdahl, K. |title=The effect of voice-onset-time on dichotic listening with consonant-vowel syllables|journal=Neuropsychologia|year=2006|volume=44 | issue = 2|pages=191–196|doi=10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2005.05.006|pmid=16023155}}</ref> first reported that in healthy adults SL pairs elicit the largest REA while, in fact, LS pairs elicit a significant left ear advantage (LEA). A study of children 5–8 years old has shown a developmental trajectory whereby long VOTs gradually start to dominate over short VOTs when LS pairs are being presented under dichotic conditions.<ref name="Westerhausen 2010">{{cite journal|author1=Westerhausen, R. |author2=Helland, T. |author3=Ofte, S. |author4=Hugdahl, K. |title=A longitudinal study of the effect of voicing on the dichotic listening ear advantage in boys and girls at age 5 to 8.|journal=Dev Neuropsychol.|year=2010|volume=35 | issue = 6|pages=):752–761|doi=10.1080/87565641.2010.508551|pmid=21038164}}</ref> Converging evidence from studies of attentional modulation of the VOT effect shows that around age 9 children lack the adult-like cognitive flexibility required to exert top-down control over stimulus-driven bottom-up processes.<ref name="Andersson 2008">{{cite journal|author1=Andersson, M. |author2=Llera, J.E. |author3=Rimol, L.M. |author4=Hugdahl, K. |title=Using dichotic listening to study bottom-up and top-down processing in children and adults.|journal=Child Neuropsychol.|year=2008|volume=14 | issue = 5|pages=470–479|doi=10.1080/09297040701756925|pmid=18608228}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=Arciuli, J. |author2=Rankine, T. |author3=Monaghan, P. |title=Auditory discrimination of voice-onset time and its relationship with reading ability.|journal=Laterality.|year=2010|volume=15 | issue = 3|pages=343–360|doi=10.1080/13576500902799671|pmid=19343572}}</ref> Arciuli et al.(2010) further demonstrated that this kind of cognitive flexibility is a predictor of proficiency with complex tasks such as reading.<ref name="Arciuli 2011">{{cite journal |author=Arciuli J |title=Manipulation of voice onset time during dichotic listening |journal=Brain Cogn |volume=76 |issue=2 |pages=233–8 |date=July 2011 |pmid=21320740 |doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2011.01.007 |url=}}</ref><ref name="Arciuli 2010">{{cite journal |vauthors=Arciuli J, Rankine T, Monaghan P |title=Auditory discrimination of voice-onset time and its relationship with reading ability |journal=Laterality |volume=15 |issue=3 |pages=343–60 |date=May 2010 |pmid=19343572 |doi=10.1080/13576500902799671 |url=}}</ref>
==Neuroscience== Dichotic listening tests can also be used as lateralized speech assessment task. Neuropsychologists have used this test to explore the role of singular neuroanatomical structures in speech perception and language asymmetry. For example, Hugdahl ''et al.'' (2003), investigated dichotic listening performance and [[frontal lobe]] function<ref name="Hugdahl 2003 58–65">{{cite journal|last=Hugdahl|first=Kenneth|title=Dichotic Listening Performance and Frontal Lobe Function|journal=Thomas Bodner, Elisabeth Weiss, Thomas Benke|year=2003|volume=16|pages=58–65|doi=10.1016/s0926-6410(02)00210-0|pmid=12589889|issue=1}}</ref> in left and right lesioned frontal lobe nonaphasiac patients compared to healthy controls. In the study, all groups were exposed to 36 dichotic trials with pairs of CV syllables and each patient was asked to state which syllable he or she heard best. As expected, the right lesioned patients showed a right ear advantage like the healthy control group but the left hemisphere lesioned patients displayed impairment when compared to both the right lesioned patients and control group. From this study, researchers concluded "dichotic listening as into a neuronal circuitry which also involves the frontal lobes, and that this may be a critical aspect of speech perception."<ref name="Hugdahl 2003 58–65"/> Similarly, Westerhausen and Hugdahl (2008)<ref name="Westerhausen 2008 1044–1054">{{cite journal|last=Westerhausen|first=Rene|author2=Kenneth Hugdahl|title=The corpus callosum in dichotic listening studies of hemispheric asymmetry: A review of clinical and experimental evidence|journal=Neuroscience and Biobehavioral Reviews|year=2008|volume=32|pages=1044–1054|doi=10.1016/j.neubiorev.2008.04.005|pmid=18499255|issue=5}}</ref> analyzed the role of the [[corpus callosum]] in dichotic listening and speech perception. After reviewing many studies, it was concluded that "...dichotic listening should be considered a test of functional inter-hemispheric interaction and connectivity, besides being a test of lateralized temporal lobe language function" and "the corpus callosum is critically involved in the top-down attentional control of dichotic listening performance, thus having a critical role in auditory laterality."<ref name="Westerhausen 2008 1044–1054"/>
==Language processing==
Dichotic listening can also be used to test the [[lateralization of brain function|hemispheric asymmetry]] of [[language processing]]. In the early 60s, Doreen Kimura reported that dichotic verbal stimuli (specifically spoken numerals) presented to a participant produced a right ear advantage (REA).<ref name="Kimura 1961">{{cite journal | author = Kimura D | year = 1961 | title = Cerebral dominance and the perception of verbal stimuli | url = | journal = Canadian Journal of Psychology | volume = 15 | issue = | pages = 166–171 | doi=10.1037/h0083219}}</ref> She attributed the right-ear advantage "to the localization of speech and language processing in the so-called dominant left hemisphere of the cerebral cortex."<ref name=Ingram2007/>{{rp|115}} According to her study, this phenomenon was related to the structure of the auditory nerves and the left-sided dominance for language processing.<ref name="Kimura 1967">{{cite journal | author = Kimura D | year = 1967 | title = Functional asymmetry of the brain in dichotic listening | url = | journal = Cortex | volume = 3 | issue = | pages = 163–178 | doi=10.1016/s0010-9452(67)80010-8}}</ref> It is important to note that REA doesn't apply to non-speech sounds. In "Hemispheric Specialization for Speech Perception," by Studdert-Kennedy and Shankweiler (1970)<ref name=Studdert-Kennedy(a)/> examine dichotic listening of CVC syllable pairs. The six stop consonants (b, d, g, p, t, k) are paired with the six vowels and a variation in the initial and final consonants are analyzed. REA is the strongest when the sound of the initial and final consonants differ and it is the weakest when solely the vowel is changed. Asbjornsen and Bryden (1996) state that "many researchers have chosen to use CV syllable pairs, usually consisting of the six stop consonants paired with the vowel \a\. Over the years, a large amount of data has been generated using such material."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Asbjornsen|first=Arve|author2=M.P. Bryden|title=Biased attention and the fused dichotic words test|journal=Neuropsychologia|year=1996|volume=34|issue=5|pages=407–11|doi=10.1016/0028-3932(95)00127-1|pmid=9148197}}</ref>
==Selective attention== In selective attention experiments, the participants may be asked to repeat aloud the content of the message they are listening to. This task is known as [[Speech shadowing|shadowing]]. As [[Colin Cherry]] (1953)<ref name=Cherry>{{cite journal | author = Cherry E. C. | year = 1953 | title = Some experiments on the recognition of speech, with one and two ears | url = | journal = Journal of the Acoustical Society of America | volume = 25 | issue = | pages = 975–979 | doi=10.1121/1.1907229}}</ref> found, people do not recall the shadowed message well, suggesting that most of the processing necessary to shadow the attended to message occurs in [[working memory]] and is not preserved in the [[long-term memory|long-term store]]. Performance on the unattended message is worse. Participants are generally able to report almost nothing about the content of the unattended message. In fact, a change from [[English language|English]] to [[German language|German]] in the unattended channel frequently goes unnoticed. However, participants are able to report that the unattended message is speech rather than non-verbal content. In addition to this, if the content of the unattended message contains certain information, such as the listener's name, then the unattended message is more likely to be noticed and remembered.<ref name="Moray 1959">{{cite journal | author = Moray N | year = 1959 | title = Attention in dichotic listening: Affective cues and the influence of instructions | url = | journal = Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology | volume = 11 | issue = | pages = 56–60 | doi=10.1080/17470215908416289}}</ref> A demonstration of this was done by Conway, Cowen, and Bunting (2001) in which they had subjects shadow words in one ear while ignoring words in the other ear. At some point, the subject's name was spoken in the ignored ear, and the question was whether the subject would report hearing their name. Subjects with a high working memory (WM) span were more capable of blocking out the distracting information.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Engle Randall W | year = 2002 | title = Working Memory Capacity as Executive Attention | doi = 10.1111/1467-8721.00160 | volume=11 | journal=Current Directions in Psychological Science | pages=19–23}}</ref> Also if the message contains sexual words then people usually notice them immediately.<ref name="Nielsen Sarason 1981">{{cite journal |author1=Nielson L. L. |author2=Sarason I. G. | year = 1981 | title = Emotion, personality, and selective attention | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 41 | issue = | pages = 945–960 | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.41.5.945 }}</ref> This suggests that the unattended information is also undergoing analysis and keywords can divert attention to it.
==Sex differences== Some data gathered from dichotic listening test experiments suggests that there is possibly a small-population sex difference in perceptual and auditory asymmetries and language laterality. According to Voyer (2011),<ref name="Voyer 2011 245–255">{{cite journal|last=Voyer|first=Daniel|title=Sex differences in dichotic listening|journal=Brain and Cognition|year=2011|volume=76|pages=245–255|doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2011.02.001|pmid=21354684|issue=2}}</ref> "Dichotic listening tasks produced homogenous effect sizes regardless of task type (verbal, non-verbal), reflecting a significant sex difference in the magnitude of laterality effects, with men obtaining larger laterality effects than women."<ref name="Voyer 2011 245–255"/>{{rp|245–246}} However, the authors discuss numerous limiting factors ranging from publication bias to small effect size. Furthermore, as discussed in "Attention, reliability, and validity of perceptual asymmetries in the fused dichotic words test,"<ref name="Voyer 2005">{{cite journal|last=Voyer|first=Daniel|author2=Jennifer Ingram|title=Attention, reliability, and validity of perceptual asymmetries in the fused dichotic word test|journal=Laterality: Asymmetries of Body, Brain, and Cognition|year=2005|volume=6|pages=545–561|doi=10.1080/13576500442000292}}</ref> women reported more "intrusions" or words presented to the uncued ear than men when presented with exogenous cues in the Fused Dichotic Word Task which suggests two possibilities: 1) Women experience more difficulty paying attention to the cued word than men and/or 2) regardless of the cue, women spread their attention evenly as opposed to men who may possibly focus in more intently on exogenous cues.<ref name="Voyer 2011 245–255"/>
==Effect of schizophrenia== A study conducted involving the dichotic listening test, with emphasis on subtypes of schizophrenia (particularly paranoid and undifferentiated), demonstrated that [[Paranoid schizophrenia|paranoid schizophrenics]] have the largest left hemisphere advantage – with undifferentiated schizophrenics (where psychotic symptoms are present but the criteria for paranoid, disorganized, or catatonic types have not been met) having the smallest.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Michelle S. |last1=Friedman |first2=Gerard E. |last2=Bruder |first3=Paul G. |last3=Nestor |first4=Barbara K. |last4=Stuart |first5=Xavier F. |last5=Amador |first6=Jack M. |last6=Gorman |date=September 2001 |title=Perceptual Asymmetries in Schizophrenia: Subtype Differences in Left Hemisphere Dominance for Dichotic Fused Words |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=158 |issue=9 |pages=1437–1440 |url=http://psychophysiology.cpmc.columbia.edu/pdf/friedman2001a.pdf |format=PDF |pmid=11532728 |doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.158.9.1437 }}</ref> The application of the dichotic listening test helped to further the beliefs that preserved left hemisphere processing is a product of paranoid schizophrenia, and in contrast, that the left hemisphere's lack of activity is a symptom of undifferentiated schizophrenia. In 1994, M.F. Green and colleagues tried to relate "the functional integration of the left hemisphere in hallucinating and nonhallucinating psychotic patients" using a dichotic listening study. The study showed that auditory hallucinations are connected to a malfunction in the left hemisphere of the brain.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Green |first1=MF |last2=Hugdahl |first2=K |last3=Mitchell |first3=S |date=March 1994 |title=Dichotic listening during auditory hallucinations in patients with schizophrenia |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=151 |issue=3 |pages=357–362 |pmid=8109643 |doi=10.1176/ajp.151.3.357 |url=http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/doi/abs/10.1176/ajp.151.3.357 |subscription=yes |via=PsychiatryOnline }}</ref>

{{Other uses}} {{advert|date=July 2018}} [[File:Doula with family.jpg|thumb|325px|A doula (left) with mother during labor]]
A '''doula''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|d|uː|l|ə}}), also known as a '''birth companion, birth coach''' or '''post-birth supporter''',<ref>{{cite web | title = What is a doula? | work = Doula UK |url=http://doula.org.uk/content/what-doula |access-date=2014-12-04 |deadurl=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141207092328/http://doula.org.uk/content/what-doula |archive-date=2014-12-07 }}</ref> is a non-medical person who assists a woman before, during, or after [[childbirth]], to provide emotional support and physical help if needed. They also may provide support to the mother's partner and family. Unlike a midwife, doulas are not medical professionals and therefore cannot administer medication. Doulas are typically certified with some courses taking over a year to complete. Practical training is involved to become certified.<ref name= Balas> {{cite journal | vauthors = Balas MC, Gale M, Kagan SH | title = Delirium doulas: an innovative approach to enhance care for critically ill older adults | journal = Critical Care Nurse | volume = 24 | issue = 4 | pages = 36–46 | date = August 2004 | pmid = 15341233 | url = http://ccn.aacnjournals.org/content/24/4/36.long }}</ref> Continuous support during birth from a person outside the mother's family or social circle, such as a Doula, is associated with reduced mortality rates, improved overall health of the mother and the baby, shorter labor time, reduced risk of a [[Caesarean section|C-Section]], and a lower need for medical interventions such as instrumental delivery or pain relief.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} Support from a Doula may also reduce mothers' negative feelings about their childbirth experience. <ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/cities-enlist-doulas-to-reduce-infant-mortality_us_59959d07e4b00dd984e37cb6|title=Cities Enlist ‘Doulas’ To Reduce Infant Mortality | first = Michael | last = Ollove | name-list-format = vanc |date=2017-08-17|work=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Bohren MA, Hofmeyr GJ, Sakala C, Fukuzawa, RK, Cuthbert A | title = Continuous support for women during childbirth | journal = The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews | issue = 7 | pages = CD003766 | date = 2017 | pmid = 28681500 | doi = 10.1002/14651858.CD003766.pub6 }}</ref> Some doulas provide [[Postpartum period|postpartum]] support, for example assisting with housework, cooking, and offering help with learning to [[Breastfeeding|breast feed]].<ref>{{cite news | first = Jeane | last = Faulkner | name-list-format = vanc | url = https://www.fitpregnancy.com/pregnancy/labor-delivery/ask-labor-nurse/4-ways-find-perfect-doula | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180124070951/https://www.fitpregnancy.com/pregnancy/labor-delivery/ask-labor-nurse/4-ways-find-perfect-doula | archive-date = 24 January 2018 | dead-url = yes | title = 4 Ways to Find the Perfect Doula|date=2014-01-06|work=Fit Pregnancy and Baby|access-date=2018-01-23}}</ref>
Major doula organizations that offer certification programs include Doula UK, DONA International, Childbirth International (CBI), Birth Arts International, International Doula Institute, Birthing From Within, The Doula Training Academy, CAPPA and the Australian Doula College. The Australian Doula College also trains end-of-life doulas.<ref>{{cite news | first = Simon | last = Little | name-list-format = vanc | url = https://globalnews.ca/news/3898905/b-c-college-trains-death-doulas-to-guide-canadians-through-their-final-days/ | title = B.C. college trains ‘death doulas’ to guide Canadians through their final days | work = CKNW Radio |access-date=2018-01-23 | date = 5 December 2017 }}</ref>
There is a movement to encourage certification, and provide documentation of it on consumer websites such as Doulas and DoulaMatch where mothers can find certified doulas, childbirth educators, yoga instructors, and other birth-related professionals.<ref name="Ballen">{{cite journal | vauthors = Ballen LE, Fulcher AJ | title = Nurses and doulas: complementary roles to provide optimal maternity care | journal = Journal of Obstetric, Gynecologic, and Neonatal Nursing | volume = 35 | issue = 2 | pages = 304–11 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16620259 | pmc = | doi = 10.1111/j.1552-6909.2006.00041.x }} </ref> Doulas not trained by a formal organization can be controversial within medical settings due to a lack of formal medical education when a discussion regarding [[medical interventions in labor]] versus pursuing [[natural childbirth]] without an [[epidural]] or [[caesarean section]] arises; however, the role of the doula is not to offer medical advice.<ref name="WSJ">{{cite news | vauthors = Hwang S | title= As 'Doulas' Enter Delivery Rooms, Conflicts Arise: Hired to Help in Childbirth, They Sometimes Clash With Doctors and Nurses | work= [[The Wall Street Journal]] | date= 2004-01-19 }}</ref>
Sometimes the term ''doula'' can also refer to a non-medical person who assists critically ill elderly people.<ref name=Balas/>
== History and etymology ==
The term ''doula'' was first used in a 1969 [[Anthropology|anthropological study]] conducted by Dana Raphael, a protégée of [[Margaret Mead]], with whom she cofounded the Human Lactation Center in [[Westport, Conn.]] in the 1970s.<ref name="Dana Raphael">{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/21/nyregion/dana-raphael-proponent-of-breast-feeding-and-the-use-of-doulas-dies-at-90.html?_r=0 | title=Dana Raphael, Proponent of Breast-Feeding and Use of Doulas, Dies at 90 | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=February 19, 2016 | access-date=January 17, 2017 | last = Roberts | first = Sam | name-list-format = vanc | authorlink = Sam Roberts (newspaper journalist)}}</ref> Raphael suggested it was a widespread practice that a female of the same species be part of childbirth, and in human societies this was traditionally a role occupied by a family member or friend whose presence contributed to successful long-term breastfeeding.<ref name="Dana Raphael"/> Raphael derived the term from [[modern Greek]] ({{lang|grc|δούλα}}, [[:wikt:doúla|doúla]], "servant-woman"), as told to her by an elderly Greek woman,<ref name="Raphael-NYT Magazine">{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/12/21/magazine/the-lives-they-lived-dana-raphael.html | title = Dana Raphael Opened Up the Mysteries of Nursing | work=[[NYT Magazine]] | date=December 21, 2016 | access-date=January 17, 2017 | last = Jones | first = Maggie | name-list-format = vanc }}</ref> Raphael also describing it as coming from "[[Aristotle]]'s time", an [[Ancient Greek]] word {{lang|grc|δούλη}} meaning "female slave".<ref name= Mander>{{cite book | vauthors = Mander R | title= Supportive care and midwifery | publisher= [[John Wiley & Sons]] | year= 2001 | isbn= 0632054255 | pages= 113–33 | chapter= The doula | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AWvQy8rtyqgC&pg=PA113#v=onepage&q&f=false }}</ref> Marshall Klaus and John Kennell, who conducted [[clinical trial]]s on the medical outcomes of doula-attended births, adopted the term to refer to a person providing labor support.<ref name= Kennel>{{cite book | vauthors = Klaus MH, Kennell JH, Klaus PH | title= The Doula Book: How A Trained Labor Companion Can Help You Have A Shorter, Easier, And Healthier Birth | publisher= [[Da Capo Press]] | year= 2002 | isbn= 0738206091 | page= 4 | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=43ebxn4cK6gC&pg=PA4#v=onepage&q&f=false }}</ref>
== Types of support ==
The overall goal of a doula is for the mother to feel safe, be informed and feel comfortable, enhancing the role of doctors and nurses which is to ensure a safe delivery for mother and child. Doulas have no [[Clinical practice|clinical role]], duties or decision-making.<ref name=Ballen/>
=== Birth ===
A birth doula is also called a labor doula. The kinds of support provided during [[childbirth]] may include physical assistance and comfort (massage, maintaining a supporting posture or providing water), emotional support (providing company, encouragement or simply talking in a soothing tone of voice), and acting as an advocate for the woman undergoing childbirth (suggesting options or supporting the woman's decisions to a medical team). Doulas may also be involved during pregnancy and [[postnatal|after birth]] (postnatal care).<ref name=Balas/>
Most doula-client relationships begin a few months before the baby is due. Before the labor, the doula and the family can develop a relationship where the mother and her partner feel free to ask questions and express fears and concerns, and where the mother can take an active role in creating a birth plan. Continuity of support by the same person is thought to be an important aspect of the relationship between doula and mother.<ref name=Mander/> Doulas may be found in hospital, community-based programs as well as private practice, doula agencies and may be reimbursed by insurance companies or out-of-pocket by clients.<ref name=Ballen/><ref name=Balas/><ref>{{cite web | title= Career Choices for Becoming a Doula | website= Become a Doula with ProDoula | language= en-US | url= https://www.prodoula.com/career-choices-for-becoming-a-doula/ | access-date= 2016-04-18 }}</ref> Because insurance companies typically do not cover the cost of hiring a doula, they are more popular among middle- and upper-class parents.<ref name=WSJ/><ref>{{cite web | url= http://missionlocal.org/2010/02/doulas-a-moms-best-friend-during-labor-grow-in-popularity/ | title= Doulas, a Mom’s Best Friend During Labor, Grow in Popularity | publisher = Missionlocal.org | date = 2010-02-22 | access-date= 2014-02-02 }}</ref>
=== Postpartum === {{See also|Postpartum confinement}} Postpartum doulas provide educational support and practical support in the home in the first weeks and months after childbirth or after adding an infant to the family. The same doula often provides both birth and postpartum services. They provide emotional support and companionship by encouraging a mother when she might be feeling overwhelmed.<ref name=DONA>{{cite web | title= DONA International – What is a doula? | publisher= Dona.org | url= http://www.dona.org/mothers/index.php | access-date= 2014-02-02 }}</ref> Other workers providing similar services are maternity nurses, newborn care specialists, and, historically, [[monthly nurse]]s.
=== Antepartum ===
An antepartum doula provides help and support to a mother who has been put on bed rest or is experiencing a high risk-pregnancy. Emotional, physical and practical support can be provided by an antepartum doula in these circumstances.
=== Other ===
The term "[[death doula]]" has also been used for practitioners caring for critically ill adults in [[geriatric nursing|geriatric care]],<ref name=Balas/> and during death.<ref>{{cite web | first = Debbie | last = Slevin | name-list-format = vanc | url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/debbie-slevin/doulas-for-the-dying_b_9601780.html | title= Doulas For The Dying | work =Huffington Post| date= 2016-04-10 | access-date= 2016-04-11 }}</ref>
== Medical aspects ==
Continuous support during labor provided by doulas (along with variety of groups such as [[nurse]]s, [[Midwifery|midwives]], other hospital staff, partners, family or friends) have been associated with improved outcomes for both mothers and children. There is research to support the beneficial effects of doulas on both maternal and newborn or infant health, including shorter delivery, fewer [[caesarean section]]s and complications, the use of fewer [[pharmaceutical drug|medications]] and fetal extraction tools, less time in [[neonatal intensive care unit]]s, positive psychological benefits for mothers, more satisfying birth experiences, and increased [[breastfeeding]].<ref name=Balas/> Cross-country research on the effects of doulas on child birth and postnatal care is complicated by the variety of settings, cultures and medical systems of individual countries and characteristics of patients.<ref name=Balas/> These benefits appear to be contingent on the doula's providing continuous rather than intermittent assistance, have some medical training and on the specific social and cultural setting within which their services are provided. Women with less education, lower incomes, less preparation for childbirth and those lacking social support may experience greater benefits from doula care than other groups.<ref name=Balas/>
Until recently, the [[American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists]] has no official position on trained labor support (of which a doula is considered to be),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanpregnancy.org/labor-and-birth/having-a-doula/|title=Having a Doula: Is a Doula for Me | work = American Pregnancy Association }}</ref> during an interview the ACOG's chairwoman of the academy’s committee on obstetric practice Sarah Kilpatrick, stated while doulas may be helpful, there are some who try to "interfere with the medical aspect of delivery." In March 2014, the ACOG put out a Consensus Statement titled "Safe Prevention of Primary Cesarean Delivery" in which it said, "Increasing women’s access to non-medical interventions during labor, such as continuous labor support, also has been shown to reduce cesarean birth rates."<ref name="pmid24553167">{{cite journal | author = American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists; Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine | title = Obstetric care consensus no. 1: safe prevention of the primary cesarean delivery | journal = Obstetrics and Gynecology | volume = 123 | issue = 3 | pages = 693–711 | date = March 2014 | pmid = 24553167 | doi = 10.1097/01.AOG.0000444441.04111.1d | url = http://www.acog.org/Resources_And_Publications/Obstetric_Care_Consensus_Series/Safe_Prevention_of_the_Primary_Cesarean_Delivery }}</ref> As more research has become available on the positive benefits of trained labor support provided by someone not employed by the hospital, in 2017, ACOG officially announced the need for all women to have access to continuous labor support outside hospital staff, and said, "Evidence suggests that, in addition to regular nursing care, continuous one-to-one emotional support provided by support personnel, such as a doula, is associated with improved outcomes for women in labor.".<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kozhimannil KB, Hardeman RR, Attanasio LB, Blauer-Peterson C, O'Brien M | title = Doula care, birth outcomes, and costs among Medicaid beneficiaries | journal = American Journal of Public Health | volume = 103 | issue = 4 | pages = e113-21 | date = April 2013 | pmid = 23409910 | pmc = 3617571 | doi = 10.2105/AJPH.2012.301201 }}</ref><ref name="pmid28121831">{{cite journal | author = Committee on Obstetric Practice; American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists | title = Committee Opinion No. 687: Approaches to Limit Intervention During Labor and Birth | journal = Obstetrics and Gynecology | volume = 129 | issue = 2 | pages = e20–e28 | date = February 2017 | pmid = 28121831 | doi = 10.1097/AOG.0000000000001905 | url = https://www.acog.org/Clinical-Guidance-and-Publications/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Obstetric-Practice/Approaches-to-Limit-Intervention-During-Labor-and-Birth }}</ref>. The official committee opinion put out by ACOG also offers other recommendations that will allow women more choice and access to more supportive care. Doulas could be utilized to help achieve many of these recommendations as they move towards better collaboration. <ref>{{cite news | first = Rachel | last = Leavitt | name-list-format = vanc |url=https://www.trainingdoulas.com/general/women-access-doula-care/|title=All women should have access to doula care |date = 2017-06-05|work=New Beginnings Doula Training|access-date=2018-07-08 }}</ref>
Doulas provide information about medications or medical interventions during childbirth and help the family decide if her practice fits the family's birth wishes such as those who decide to have an [[epidural]] or otherwise do not undertake [[natural childbirth]].<ref name="WSJ" /><ref name="NYT">{{cite news | vauthors = Paul P | title= And the Doula Makes Four | work= [[The New York Times]] | date= 2008-03-02 | url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/02/fashion/02doula.html | access-date= 2012-03-22 }}</ref> Doulas acting beyond the role of social support and advocacy by providing medical advice, practicing outside their scope of practice may be acting as a traditional birth attendant.<ref name="Ballen" />
In 2017 the United Kingdom's Royal College of Midwives published a position statement on doulas.<ref>https://www.rcm.org.uk/sites/default/files/Doulas%20V.2_3.pdf</ref>
== Training and certification ==
There is a lack of standardization and oversight of doulas, with multiple organizations providing different courses with varying requirements.<ref>{{cite web | title= What You Should Know Before You Become A Doula | website= ProDoula | language= en-US | url= https://www.prodoula.com/what-you-should-know-before-you-become-a-doula/ | access-date= 2016-04-18 }}</ref> There is no formal or universally recognized certification process or training requirements, and anyone can refer to themselves as a doula.<ref name=NYT/> No academic credentials such as a college or university diploma, or high school equivalency are required.<ref name=WSJ/> . Doulamatch.net, an online referral page for doulas, has offered a list of items that students should look for as they begin looking for training. Amy Gilliland, a researcher on doula care and culture, also lists some qualities a training program should have. <ref>{{cite news | first = Rachel | last = Leavitt | name-list-format = vanc | url = https://www.trainingdoulas.com/doula-training/best-doula-training/|title=What Makes the Best Doula Training Program? | date=2017-06-13|work=New Beginnings Doula Training|access-date=2018-07-08 }}</ref> Some theorists have stated that it may take college level work or more in depth online eduction in order to provide some of the communication skills that may be necessary.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Meadow SL | title = Defining the doula's role: fostering relational autonomy | journal = Health Expectations | volume = 18 | issue = 6 | pages = 3057–68 | date = December 2015 | pmid = 25327532 | pmc = 5810740 | doi = 10.1111/hex.12290 }}</ref>
Being a doula does not specifically require any medical training, although it is not uncommon for doulas to have received certification or medical training of some kind.<ref name=WSJ/> In [[North America]], training generally takes the form of a two- to three-day seminar, and some experience with childbirth.<ref>{{cite web | title= Doula Training Become A Doula | website= ProDoula | language= en-US | url= https://www.prodoula.com/ | access-date= 2016-04-18 }}</ref> Trainees may have hands-on practice with various techniques used during childbirth, including maternal positions and movements, relaxation and breathing exercises and other measures that could be used for comfort. Certification can occur through organizations at various levels (local, national or international) and some require positive evaluations from medical professionals. Certification may also require, in addition to attending a training course, time spent working or learning about maternity care and childbirth classes and possibly a written exam.<ref name=Balas/> Some doulas train through distance education.<ref name=Ballen/> Research also supports the effectiveness of female friends or relatives, after minimal training, as a low-cost alternative to professional doulas.<ref name="Campbell">{{cite journal | vauthors = Campbell D, Scott KD, Klaus MH, Falk M | title = Female relatives or friends trained as labor doulas: outcomes at 6 to 8 weeks postpartum | journal = Birth | volume = 34 | issue = 3 | pages = 220–7 | date = September 2007 | pmid = 17718872 | pmc = | doi = 10.1111/j.1523-536X.2007.00174.x }} </ref>
Disputes between doctors, nurses and doulas have been described as a "turf battle",<ref name =WSJ/> though it is also recognized that doulas and nurses can occupy complementary roles that provide opportunities for mutual learning and assistance.<ref name=Ballen/> Some hospitals have created internal doula training programs to reduce conflict between doulas and medical staff.<ref name=WSJ/><ref>{{cite web | title= Hospital "Credentialing" For Doulas? Yea or Nay? | website= Become a Doula with ProDoula | language= en-US | url= https://www.prodoula.com/hospital-credentialing-for-doulas-yea-or-nay/ | access-date= 2016-04-18 }}</ref>

The term "'''encounter'''", in the context of existential-humanism (like [[existential therapy]]), has the specific meaning of an authentic, [[wikt:congruent|congruent]] meeting between individuals.
==Examples== Some uses of the concept of encountering:
* [[Jacob L. Moreno]] ''Invitations to an Encounter'', 1914 * [[Martin Buber]] frequently uses this term and associated ideas. * [[Irvin Yalom]] in his book "Existential Psychotherapy". * [[Carl Rogers]], in [[encounter group]]s and [[person-centered psychotherapy]]. * [[Jerzy Grotowski]]'s notion of a "poor theatre" – "The core of the theatre is an encounter". * [[R D Laing]] contrasts encounter with [[collusion]] in much of his work, especially ''[[Self and Others]]''.
[[Category:Existentialist concepts]] [[Category:Existential therapy]]
{{psych-stub}}

{{Infobox Government agency | agency_name = Food Standards Australia New Zealand | nativename = FSANZ | logo = Food Standards Australia New Zealand logo.png | logo_width = | logo_caption = | seal = | seal_width = | seal_caption = | formed = 1991 | date1 = | date1_name = | date2 = | date2_name = | preceding1 = | preceding2 = | dissolved = | superseding = | jurisdiction = | headquarters = | employees = 102<ref>{{cite report|title=APS Statistical Bulletin 2015-2016|url=http://www.apsc.gov.au/about-the-apsc/parliamentary/aps-statistical-bulletin/statisticalbulletin1516/table2total|publisher=Australian Public Service Commission|date=September 2016}}</ref> | budget = | chief1_name = | chief1_position = | parent_agency = | website = {{URL|http://www.foodstandards.gov.au/}} | footnotes = }}
'''Food Standards Australia New Zealand''' ('''FSANZ''') ([[Maori language|Māori]]: ''Te Mana Kounga Kai - Ahitereiria me Aotearoa''), formerly '''Australia New Zealand Food Authority''' ('''ANZFA'''), is the governmental body responsible for developing [[food standards]] for [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Food Standards Australia New Zealand |url=http://www.foodstandards.gov.au/ |publisher=Food Standards Australia New Zealand}}</ref>
FSANZ develops food standards after consulting with other government agencies and stakeholders. The recommendations made by the body are open and accountable, and based upon a rigorous scientific assessment of risk to public health and safety.
All decisions made by FSANZ must be approved by the [[Australia and New Zealand Food Regulation Ministerial Council]], which is composed of the Health Minister from each of the Australian states and territories, and the [[Minister of Health (New Zealand)|Health Minister]] from New Zealand, as well as other participating Ministers nominated by each jurisdiction.<ref>{{cite web |title=Board Meeting Outcomes |url=http://www.foodstandards.gov.au/aboutfsanz/boardmeetingoutcomes/ |publisher=Food Standards Australia New Zealand}}</ref> This may lead to political interference in the decision: for example the decision made over [[hemp]] seed, when the Food Standards scientists recommended that hemp seed be allowed for sale, the ministers vetoed this because they did not want to appear soft on drugs.
Publications from FSANZ include the ''[[Australian Total Diet Survey]]'' and ''[[Shoppers' Guide to Food Additives and labels]]''.
This authority is sometimes cited variously as Australia and New Zealand Food Standards/Safety Authority (ANZFSA),<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia | url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;query=Id%3A%22chamber%2Fhansardr%2F2007-06-20%2F0225%22 | house=House of Representatives | day=20 |month=Jun |year=2007 |speaker=[[Nicola Roxon|ROXON, the Hon. Nicola Louise]] |position=MP |title=20 Jun 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Bills_Legislation/bd/bd0001/01bd120 |title=Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill 2001 |publisher=Commonwealth of Australia }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 =Urbana | first1 = J.D. | last2 = Carakostasb | first2 = M.C. | last3 = Brusickc | first3 = D.J. |date=January 2013 | title =Steviol glycoside safety: Is the genotoxicity database sufficient? | journal = [[Food and Chemical Toxicology]] | volume = 51 | pages = 386–390 | doi = 10.1016/j.fct.2012.10.016 | pmid = 23103588 | url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0278691512007533?np=y}}</ref> possibly incorrect nomenclature arising due to confusion with the non-acronymic older version of the short-name ANZFA, and with the acronym of the New Zealand authority, [[New Zealand Food Safety Authority|NZFSA]] (pronounced enzfissar, similar to anzfessar of ANZFSA) which previously managed such questions in New Zealand.

{{Infobox climber | image = <!-- name.jpg --> | image_size = <!--Only for images narrower than 220 pixels.--> | caption = | name = Fritz Kasparek | nationality = Austrian | birth_date = {{birth date|1910|07|03|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Vienna]], [[Austria-Hungary]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1954|06|06|1910|07|03|df=y}} | death_place = [[Salcantay]], [[Peru]] | residence = | education = | occupation = | height = <!-- {{convert|}} (yyyy) --> | weight = <!-- {{convert|}} (yyyy) --> | typeofclimber = | highestgrade = | highestredpoint = | highestonsight = | knownfor = [[Eiger]] north face first ascent | firstascents = {{Plainlist| * [[Tre Cime di Lavaredo]] Cima Grande * [[Eiger]] north face }} | namedroutes = | majorascents = | worlds = | medaltemplates = | show-medals = | retired = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> }} '''Fritz Kasparek''' (3 July 1910 – 6 June 1954) was an Austrian mountaineer who was on the team that made the first ascent of the [[Eiger]] north face.
Kasparek gained his first alpine experiences on the ''Peilstein'' in the [[Vienna Woods|Wienerwald]] and in the [[Ennstaler Alps]]. After [[Emilio Comici]] had been the first to climb the north face of the Cima Grande of the [[Tre Cime di Lavaredo]] in 1933, in February 1938 Kasparek and Sepp Brunnhuber made the first winter ascent.
On 24 July 1938, with [[Anderl Heckmair]], [[Ludwig Vörg]] and [[Heinrich Harrer]], he made the first ascent of the [[Great north faces of the Alps|north face]] of the [[Eiger]]. This climb, previously deemed impossible and described by [[Reinhold Messner]] as "a glorious moment in the history of mountaineering and a great sensation, since several climbers had previously perished on the face",<ref>Reinhold Messner, ''The Big Walls: From the North Face of the Eiger to the South Face of Dhaulagiri'', p. 105, Crowood 2001. {{ISBN|1-86126-467-4}}</ref> made headlines around the world<ref>[https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0B15F73B5C1B7A93C4AB178CD85F4C8385F9&scp=1&sq=eiger%201938&st=cse "Climbers conquer dread Eiger peak"], ''The New York Times'', July 26, 1938</ref> and is recounted in Heinrich Harrer's 1958 book, ''[[The White Spider]]''.
Kasparek died in 1954, falling to his death through a broken [[snow cornice]] near the peak of the [[Salcantay]] in [[Peru]].
==References== <references/>
== Autobiography == * ''Ein Bergsteiger. Fritz Kasparek, einer der Bezwinger der Eiger-Nordwand erzählt von seinen Bergfahrten'', Verlag Das Bergland-Buch, Salzburg 1939 * ''Vom Peilstein zur Eiger-Nordwand. Erlebnisse eines Bergsteigers. New extended and improved edition of "Ein Bergsteiger"'', Verlag Das Bergland-Buch, Salzburg 1951
{{Authority control}}

'''Fritz Luchsinger''' (March 8, 1921 – 28 April 1983) was a Swiss mountaineer. Together with [[Ernst Reiss]] he made the [[first ascent]] of [[Lhotse]] (8,516 m), the fourth highest mountain in the world, on 18 May 1956.<ref name=AAJ_1957/> During the approach march Luchsinger came down with severe [[appendicitis]], and had to recuperate in a room given to the Swiss expedition by the lama of [[Tengboche]] monastery.<ref name=sfar/>
Luchsinger disappeared during an attempt on [[Shishapangma]] in 1983.<ref name=Scott2014/>

Adams Carter | url = http://publications.americanalpineclub.org/articles/12195712100/Everest-Lhotse-1956 | accessdate = 10 April 2016}}</ref> <ref name=Scott2014> {{cite book | title = Shishapangma: The alpine-style first ascent of the South-West Face | author1 = Scott, Doug | author2 = MacIntyre, Alex | publisher = Vertebrate Publishing | year = 2014 | url = https://books.google.ca/books?id=U6usAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT334&lpg=PT334&dq=Shishapangma+1983+luchsinger&source=bl&ots=lMvxASq-TD&sig=Ndmz6LLsZ1o5OKidnfp4VTUtnt8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiPrIvUg4XMAhWBlIMKHWTKCP8Q6AEILzAD#v=onepage&q=Shishapangma%201983%20luchsinger&f=false | accessdate = 10 April 2016}}</ref> <ref name=sfar> {{cite web | title = 50 Years Everest-Lhotse Expedition: The Swiss Mount Everest/Lhotse Expedition 1956 | url = http://www.sfar-evev06.ch/en/expeditions/everest_lhotse56.html | publisher = Swiss Foundation for Alpine Research | accessdate = 10 April 2016 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091003064234/http://www.sfar-evev06.ch/en/expeditions/everest_lhotse56.html | archivedate= 2009-10-03}}</ref> }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Luchsinger, Fritz}} [[Category:Swiss mountain climbers]] [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:1983 deaths]] [[Category:Mountaineering deaths]]

[[File:Gravure peste - Quartier Belsunce.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Contemporary engraving of Marseille during the Great Plague]] [[Image:Avis au public Marseille 1720.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Public notice on the disposal of corpses during the Great Plague, 1720]] The '''Great Plague of Marseille''' was the last of the significant European outbreaks of [[bubonic plague]]. Arriving in [[Marseille]], [[France]] in 1720, the disease killed a total of 100,000 people: 50,000 in the city during the next two years and another 50,000 to the north in surrounding provinces and towns.<ref> Duchêne & Contrucci (2004).</ref>
Despite the large number of deaths, Marseille recovered quickly from the plague outbreak. Economic activity took only a few years to recover, as trade expanded to the West Indies and Latin America. By 1765, the growing population was back at its pre-1720 level.
==Pre-plague city==
===Sanitation board=== At the end of the plague of 1580, the people at Marseilles took dramatic measures to attempt to control the future spread of disease. The city council of Marseilles established a sanitation board, whose members were to be drawn from the city council as well as the doctors of the city. The exact founding date of the board is unknown, but its existence is first mentioned in a 1622 text of the [[Parlement|Parlement of Aix]]. The newly established sanitation board made a series of recommendations to maintain the health of the city.<ref>p. 17 Françoise Hildesheimer</ref>
They established a bureaucracy to maintain the health of Marseilles. In addition to protecting the city from exterior vulnerabilities, the sanitation board sought to build a public infrastructure. The first public hospital of Marseilles was also built during this time period, and was given a full-sized staff of doctors and nurses. Additionally, the sanitation board was responsible for the accreditation of local doctors. Citing the vast amount of misinformation that propagates during a plague, the sanitation board sought to at a minimum provide citizens with a list of doctors who were believed to be credible.<ref>p. 53, Françoise Hildesheimer</ref>
The sanitation board was one of the first executive bodies formed by the city of Marseilles. It was staffed to support the board's increasing responsibilities.
===Quarantine system===
The Sanitation Board established a three-tiered control and quarantine system. Members of the board inspected all incoming ships and gave them one of three "bills of health". The “bill of health” then determined the level of access to the city by the ship and its cargo.
A delegation of members of the sanitation board was to greet every incoming ship. They reviewed the captain’s log, which recorded every city the ship had landed in, and checked it against the sanitation board's master list of cities throughout the Mediterranean that had rumors of recent plague incidents. The delegation also inspected all the cargo, crew and passengers, looking for signs of possible disease. If the team saw signs of disease, the ship was not allowed to land at a Marseilles dock.
If the ship passed that first test and there were no signs of disease, but the ship’s itinerary included a city with documented plague activity, the ship was sent to the second tier of quarantine, at islands outside of Marseilles harbor. The criteria for the ''[[lazarettos|lazarets]]'' were ventilation (to drive off what was thought to be the miasma of disease), be near the sea to facilitate communication and pumping of water to clean, and to be isolated yet easily accessible.<ref>p. 361, Roger Duchêne et Jean Contrucci</ref>
even a clean bill of health for a ship required a minimum of 18 days' quarantine at the off island. During such time, the crew would be held in one of the lazarettos/lazarets that were constructed around the city. The lazarettos were also classified in relation to bills of health given to the ship and individuals. With a clean bill, a crewman went to the largest quarantine site, which was equipped with stores and was large enough to accommodate many ships and crews at a time. If crew were believed subject to a possibility of plague, they were sent to the more isolated quarantine site, which was built on an island off the coast of the Marseille harbor. The crew and passengers were required to wait there for 50 to 60 days to see if they developed any sign of plague.<ref>p. 366, Roger Duchêne et Jean Contrucci</ref>
Once crews served their time, they were allowed into the city in order to sell their goods and enjoy themselves prior to departure.
==Outbreak and fatalities== This great outburst of plague was the last recurrence of a [[Second plague pandemic|pandemic of bubonic plague]], following the devastating episodes which began in the early-fourteenth century with the 1331 [[Black Death]].<ref>Duchene and Contrucci (2004), Chronology. Marseille suffered from epidemics of the European Black Death in 1348 (recurring intermittently until 1361), in 1580 and 1582, and in 1649-1650.</ref> In 1720, ''[[Yersinia pestis]]'' arrived at the port of Marseille from the [[Levant]] upon the merchant ship ''Grand-Saint-Antoine.'' The vessel had departed from [[Sidon]] in [[Lebanon]], having previously called at [[Smyrna]], [[Tripoli]], and plague-ridden [[Cyprus]]. A Turkish passenger was the first to be infected and soon died, followed by several crew members and the ship's surgeon. The ship was refused entry to the port of [[Livorno]].
When it arrived at Marseille, it was promptly placed under [[quarantine]] in the ''[[Lazaretto|lazaret]]'' by the port authorities.<ref> Duchêne & Contrucci (2004), pages 361-362.</ref> Due largely to Marseille's monopoly on French trade with the Levant, this important port had a large stock of imported goods in warehouses. It was also expanding its trade with other areas of the Middle East and emerging markets in the New World. Powerful city merchants needed the [[silk]] and [[cotton]] cargo of the ship for the great medieval fair at [[Beaucaire, Gard|Beaucaire]] and pressured authorities to lift the quarantine.
[[Image:Mur de la peste.jpg|thumb|left|The 16th-century ''"mur de la peste"'' (plague wall), Provence]]
A few days later, the disease broke out in the city. Hospitals were quickly overwhelmed, and residents panicked, driving the sick from their homes and out of the city. Mass graves were dug but were quickly filled. Eventually the number of dead overcame city public health efforts, until thousands of corpses lay scattered and in piles around the city.
Attempts to stop the spread of plague included an Act of the [[Parlement|Parlement of Aix]] that levied the death penalty for any communication between Marseille and the rest of Provence. To enforce this separation, a plague wall, the ''Mur de la Peste'', was erected across the countryside. The wall was built of dry stone, 2 m high and 70 cm thick, with guard posts set back from the wall. Remains of the wall can still be seen in different parts of the Plateau de Vaucluse.
During a two-year period, 50,000 of Marseille's total population of 90,000 died. An additional 50,000 people in other areas succumbed as the plague spread north, eventually reaching [[Aix-en-Provence]], [[Arles]], [[Apt, Vaucluse|Apt]] and [[Toulon]]. Estimates indicate an overall death rate of between 25%-50% for the population in the larger area, with the city of Marseille at 40%, the area of Toulon at above 50%, and the area of Aix and Arles at 25%.
After the plague subsided, the royal government strengthened the plague defenses of the port, building the waterside [[:fr:Lazaret d'Arenc|''Lazaret d'Arenc'']]. A double line of fifteen-foot walls ringed the whitewashed compound, pierced on the waterside to permit the offloading of cargo from lighters. Merchantmen were required to pass inspection at an island further out in the harbour, where crews and cargoes were examined.<ref>[http://mistraletnoroit.free.fr/spip.php?article1 "La peste et les lazarets de Marseille"]; briefly noted in [[Simon Schama]], ''Landscape and Memory'' (1995): 245f.</ref>
==Recent research== [[File:Bubonic plague victims-mass grave in Martigues, France 1720-1721.jpg|thumb|Bubonic plague victims in a mass grave from 1720 to 1721 in [[Martigues, France]]]] In 1998, an excavation of a mass grave of victims of the bubonic plague outbreak was conducted by scholars from the [[Université de la Méditerranée]].<ref>Signoli, Seguy, Biraben, Dutour & Belle (2002).</ref> The excavation provided an opportunity to study more than 200 skeletons from an area in the second [[Municipal arrondissements of France|arrondissement]] in Marseille, known as the Monastery of the Observance. In addition to modern laboratory testing, archival records were studied to determine the conditions and dates surrounding the use of this mass grave. This multidisciplinary approach revealed previously unknown facts and insights concerning the epidemic of 1722. The reconstruction of the skull of one body, a 15-year-old boy, revealed the first historical evidence of an [[autopsy]] dated to the spring of 1722. The anatomic techniques used appear to be identical to those described in a surgical book dating from 1708.
==See also== * [[List of Bubonic plague outbreaks]] * [[Peasants' Revolt]] * [[Plague of Justinian]] * [[Popular revolt in late medieval Europe]] * [[Plague Riot]] * [[Third plague pandemic|Third Pandemic (1855–1960)]]
